<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Copenhagen skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Copenhagen</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Good_article&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Good article (page does not exist)">Template:Good article</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_dmy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use dmy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use dmy dates</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-move-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-move-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-move-indef</a>
{{#invoke:Infobox|infobox}}
</p><p><b>Copenhagen</b> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-da&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-da (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-da</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPA-da&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPA-da (page does not exist)">Template:IPA-da</a> <small>(<span class="unicode haudio" style="white-space:nowrap;"><span class="fn"><a href="/wiki/File:Loudspeaker.svg" title="File:Loudspeaker.svg">About this sound</a>&#160;<a href="/w/index.php?title=Special:Upload&amp;wpDestFile=Da-K%C3%B8benhavn.ogg" class="new" title="Da-København.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</small>) is the capital and most populous city of <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a>, with an <a href="/wiki/Urban_area" title="Urban area">urban</a> population of 1,230,728 and a <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_area" title="Metropolitan area">metropolitan</a> population of 1,967,727 (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>). It is situated on the eastern coast of <a href="/wiki/Zealand" title="Zealand">Zealand</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> northwest of <a href="/wiki/Malm%C3%B6" title="Malmö">Malmö</a>, Sweden and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> northeast of <a href="/wiki/Odense" title="Odense">Odense</a>. The city stretches across parts of the island of <a href="/wiki/Amager" title="Amager">Amager</a> and also contains the enclave of <a href="/wiki/Frederiksberg_Municipality" title="Frederiksberg Municipality">Frederiksberg</a>, a municipality in its own right.
</p><p>Originally a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Viking&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Viking (page does not exist)">Viking</a> fishing village founded in the 10th century, Copenhagen became the capital of Denmark in the early 15th century. During the 17th century, under the reign of <a href="/wiki/Christian_IV_of_Denmark" title="Christian IV of Denmark">Christian IV</a>, it developed into an important regional centre, consolidating its position as capital of Denmark and Norway with its institutions, defences and armed forces. After suffering from the effects of plague and fire in the 18th century, the city underwent a period of redevelopment which included the prestigious district of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederiksstaden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederiksstaden (page does not exist)">Frederiksstaden</a> and cultural institutions such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Danish_Theatre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Danish Theatre (page does not exist)">Royal Theatre</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Danish_Academy_of_Fine_Arts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts (page does not exist)">Royal Academy of Fine Arts</a>. After further disasters in the early 19th century when <a href="/w/index.php?title=Horatio_Nelson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Horatio Nelson (page does not exist)">Nelson</a> attacked the Danish fleet and bombarded the city, rebuilding during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_Golden_Age&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish Golden Age (page does not exist)">Danish Golden Age</a> brought a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Neoclassical_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Neoclassical architecture (page does not exist)">Neoclassical</a> look to Copenhagen's architecture. Later, following the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Second_World_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Second World War (page does not exist)">Second World War</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Finger_Plan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Finger Plan (page does not exist)">Finger Plan</a> fostered the creation of housing and businesses along the five urban railway routes stretching out from the city centre.
</p><p>Since the turn of the millennium, Copenhagen has seen strong urban and cultural development, facilitated by investment in its institutions and infrastructure. The city is the <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Denmark" title="Culture of Denmark">cultural</a>, <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Denmark" title="Economy of Denmark">economic</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Politics_of_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Politics of Denmark (page does not exist)">governmental</a> centre of Denmark and one of the major financial centres of Northern Europe with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Stock_Exchange&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Stock Exchange (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Stock Exchange</a>. In 2012, Copenhagen was third in the ranking of the richest cities in the world in terms of gross earnings, dropping from first place in 2009. Since the completion of the <a href="/wiki/%C3%98resund_Bridge" title="Øresund Bridge">Øresund Bridge</a>, the metropolitan area of Copenhagen has become increasingly integrated with the Swedish province of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scania (page does not exist)">Scania</a> and its largest city, Malmö, known as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%98resund_region&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Øresund region (page does not exist)">Øresund Region</a>. With a number of bridges connecting the various districts, the cityscape is characterized by parks, promenades and waterfronts. Copenhagen's landmarks such as <a href="/wiki/Tivoli_Gardens" title="Tivoli Gardens">Tivoli Gardens</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Little_Mermaid_Statue&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Little Mermaid Statue (page does not exist)">Little Mermaid Statue</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amalienborg_Palace&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amalienborg Palace (page does not exist)">Amalienborg</a> and <a href="/wiki/Christiansborg_Palace" title="Christiansborg Palace">Christianbsorg</a> palaces, <a href="/wiki/Rosenborg_Castle" title="Rosenborg Castle">Rosenborg Castle</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederik%27s_Church&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederik's Church (page does not exist)">Frederik's Church</a>, and many museums, restaurants and nightclubs are significant tourist attractions. In addition to recent developments in the city <a href="/wiki/Service_sector" title="Service sector" class="mw-redirect">service sector</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Pharmaceutical" title="Pharmaceutical" class="mw-redirect">pharmaceutical</a> industry, there have been a number of initiatives in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Clean_technology&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Clean technology (page does not exist)">clean technology</a>, matching the city's aim to be carbon-neutral by 2025.
</p><p>Copenhagen has over 94,000 students enrolled in its largest universities and institutions, including the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Copenhagen" title="University of Copenhagen">University of Copenhagen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Business_School" title="Copenhagen Business School">Copenhagen Business School</a>,  <a href="/w/index.php?title=Metropolitan_University_College&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Metropolitan University College (page does not exist)">Metropolitan University College</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Technical_University_of_Denmark" title="Technical University of Denmark">Technical University of Denmark</a>. The University of Copenhagen, founded in 1479, is the oldest university in Denmark, and has repeatedly been ranked as one of the best universities in Europe. Copenhagen is home to the <a href="/wiki/F.C._Copenhagen" title="F.C. Copenhagen">FC København</a> and <a href="/wiki/Br%C3%B8ndby_IF" title="Brøndby IF">Brøndby</a> football clubs and the ice hockey teams <a href="/w/index.php?title=R%C3%B8dovre_Mighty_Bulls&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rødovre Mighty Bulls (page does not exist)">Rødovre Mighty Bulls</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Herlev_Hornets&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Herlev Hornets (page does not exist)">Herlev Eagles</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hvidovre_Ligahockey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hvidovre Ligahockey (page does not exist)">Hvidovre Ligahockey</a>. The annual <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Marathon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Marathon (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Marathon</a> was established in 1980. Copenhagen is one of the most bicycle-friendly cities in the world. The <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Metro" title="Copenhagen Metro">Copenhagen Metro</a> serves central Copenhagen together with the <a href="/wiki/S-train" title="S-train">S-train</a> network connecting the outlying boroughs. Serving almost 2 million passengers a month, <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Airport" title="Copenhagen Airport">Copenhagen Airport, Kastrup</a>, is the largest airport in the Nordic countries.
</p>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-51"><a href="#Notable_people"><span class="tocnumber">14</span> <span class="toctext">Notable people</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-52"><a href="#Twin_cities"><span class="tocnumber">15</span> <span class="toctext">Twin cities</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-53"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">16</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-54"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">17</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-55"><a href="#Further_reading"><span class="tocnumber">18</span> <span class="toctext">Further reading</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-56"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">19</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p>The city's origin as a harbour and a place of commerce is reflected in its name. Its original designation, from which the contemporary Danish name is derived, was <i>Køpmannæhafn</i>, meaning "merchants' harbour", often simply <i>Hafn</i> or <i>Havn</i>. The English <a href="/wiki/Cognate" title="Cognate">cognate</a> would be <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chapmen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chapmen (page does not exist)">Chapman</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Harbor" title="Harbor">haven</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> The English name for the city is derived from its <a href="/wiki/Low_German" title="Low German">Low German</a> name, <i>Kopenhagen</i>. The chemical element <a href="/wiki/Hafnium" title="Hafnium">hafnium</a> is also named for Copenhagen, whose <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> name is <i>Hafnia</i>,.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The bacterium <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hafnia_(bacterium)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hafnia (bacterium) (page does not exist)">Hafnia</a></i> is also named after Copenhagen, being coined in 1954 by Vagn Møller of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=State_Serum_Institute&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="State Serum Institute (page does not exist)">State Serum Institute</a> in Copenhagen.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:K%C3%B8benhavn1500.jpg" title="File:København1500.jpg">File:København1500.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Reconstruction of Copenhagen as of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Circa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Circa (page does not exist)">Template:Circa</a></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_history">Early history</span></h3>
<p>Although the earliest historical records of Copenhagen are from the end of the 12th century, recent archaeological finds in connection with work on the city's metro have revealed the remains of a large merchant's mansion near today's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kongens_Nytorv&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kongens Nytorv (page does not exist)">Kongens Nytorv</a> from c. 1020. Excavations in Pilestræde have also led to the discovery of a well from the late 12th century, and the remains of an old church with graves dating to the 11th century have been unearthed near where <a href="/wiki/Str%C3%B8get" title="Strøget">Strøget</a> meets <a href="/w/index.php?title=R%C3%A5dhuspladsen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rådhuspladsen (page does not exist)">Rådhuspladsen</a>. These finds indicate that Copenhagen's origins go back at least as far as the 11th century, while substantial discoveries of flint tools in the area provide evidence of settlements as far back as the <a href="/wiki/Stone_Age" title="Stone Age">Stone Age</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> Many historians believe the town dates to the late <a href="/wiki/Viking_Age" title="Viking Age">Viking Age</a>, and was possibly founded by <a href="/wiki/Sweyn_Forkbeard" title="Sweyn Forkbeard">Sweyn I Forkbeard</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The natural harbour and good herring stocks seem to have attracted fishermen and merchants to the area on a seasonal basis from the 11th century and more permanently in the 13th century.<sup id="cite_ref-khdsd_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-khdsd-4">[4]</a></sup> The first habitations were probably centred around <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gammel_Strand&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gammel Strand (page does not exist)">Gammel Strand</a> (literally "old shore") in the 11th century or even earlier.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>The earliest written mention of the town was in the 12th century when <a href="/wiki/Saxo_Grammaticus" title="Saxo Grammaticus">Saxo Grammaticus</a> in <a href="/wiki/Gesta_Danorum" title="Gesta Danorum">Gesta Danorum</a> referred to it as <i>Portus Mercatorum</i>, which translates into Merchants' Harbour or in the <a href="/wiki/Danish_language" title="Danish language">Danish</a> of the time <i>Købmannahavn</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-metro1415_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-metro1415-6">[6]</a></sup> Traditionally, Copenhagen's founding has been dated to <a href="/wiki/Absalon" title="Absalon">Bishop Absalon</a>'s construction of a modest fortress on the little island of <a href="/wiki/Slotsholmen" title="Slotsholmen">Slotsholmen</a> in 1167 where <a href="/wiki/Christiansborg_Palace" title="Christiansborg Palace">Christiansborg Palace</a> stands today.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The construction of the fortress was in response to attacks by <a href="/wiki/Wends" title="Wends">Wendish</a> pirates who plagued the coastline during the 12th century.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Defensive ramparts and moats were completed and by 1177 St. Clemens Church had been built. Attacks by the Germans continued, and after the original fortress was eventually destroyed by the marauders, it was replaced by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Castle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Castle (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Castle</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_Ages">Middle Ages</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Arsenal_Museum_Copenhagen_backend.jpg" title="File:Arsenal Museum Copenhagen backend.jpg">File:Arsenal Museum Copenhagen backend.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Tøjhus Arsenal (1604)</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Old_Stock_Exchange_Copenhagen,_pic-001.JPG" title="File:Old Stock Exchange Copenhagen, pic-001.JPG">File:Old Stock Exchange Copenhagen, pic-001.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Børsen (completed 1640)</div></div></div>
<p>In 1186, a letter from <a href="/wiki/Pope_Urban_III" title="Pope Urban III">Pope Urban III</a> states that the castle of <i>Hafn</i> (Copenhagen) and its surrounding lands including the town of Hafn were given to Archbishop Absalom of Roskilde by King <a href="/wiki/Valdemar_I_of_Denmark" title="Valdemar I of Denmark">Valdemar I</a>. On Absalom's death, the property was to come into the ownership of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Diocese_of_Roskilde_(Roman-Catholic)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Diocese of Roskilde (Roman-Catholic) (page does not exist)">Bishopric of Roskilde</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-khdsd_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-khdsd-4">[4]</a></sup> Around 1200, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Church_of_Our_Lady_(Copenhagen)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Church of Our Lady (Copenhagen) (page does not exist)">Church of Our Lady</a> was constructed on higher ground to the northeast of the town which began to expand around it.<sup id="cite_ref-khdsd_4-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-khdsd-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p>The town rose in prominence but was repeatedly attacked by the <a href="/wiki/Hanseatic_League" title="Hanseatic League">Hanseatic League</a>. As the fishing industry thrived in Copenhagen, particularly in the trade of herring, the city began expanding to the north of Slotsholmen.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In 1254, it received a charter as a city under Bishop <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jakob_Erlandsen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jakob Erlandsen (page does not exist)">Jakob Erlandsen</a><sup id="cite_ref-Copenhagen1898_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Copenhagen1898-7">[7]</a></sup> who garnered support from the local fishing merchants against the king by granting them special privileges.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In the mid 1330s, the first land assessment of the city was published.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>With the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Kalmar_Union" title="Kalmar Union">Kalmar Union</a> (1397–1523) between Denmark, Norway and Sweden, by about 1416 Copenhagen had emerged as the capital of Denmark when <a href="/wiki/Eric_of_Pomerania" title="Eric of Pomerania">Eric of Pomerania</a> moved his seat to Copenhagen Castle.<sup id="cite_ref-Ingebritsen2006_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ingebritsen2006-8">[8]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The University of Copenhagen was inaugurated on 1 June 1479 by King <a href="/wiki/Christian_I_of_Denmark" title="Christian I of Denmark">Christian I</a>, following approval from Pope <a href="/wiki/Sixtus_IV" title="Sixtus IV" class="mw-redirect">Sixtus IV</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-histuni_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-histuni-9">[9]</a></sup> The university's Christian role in Danish society was forced to change during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reformation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reformation (page does not exist)">Reformation</a> in the late 1530s.<sup id="cite_ref-histuni_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-histuni-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="16th_and_17th_centuries">16th and 17th centuries</span></h3>
<p>In disputes prior to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_Reformation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish Reformation (page does not exist)">Reformation</a> of 1536, the city which had been faithful to <a href="/wiki/Christian_II_of_Denmark" title="Christian II of Denmark">Christian II</a> was successfully besieged in 1523 by the forces of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederik_I_of_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederik I of Denmark (page does not exist)">Frederik I</a>, who supported <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lutheranism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lutheranism (page does not exist)">Lutheranism</a>. Thereafter, Copenhagen's defences were reinforced with a series of towers along the city wall. After an extended siege from July 1535 to July 1536 during which the city supported Christian II's alliance with <a href="/wiki/Malm%C3%B6" title="Malmö">Malmö</a> and <a href="/wiki/L%C3%BCbeck" title="Lübeck">Lübeck</a>, it was finally forced to capitulate to <a href="/wiki/Christian_III_of_Denmark" title="Christian III of Denmark">Christian III</a>. During the second half of the century, the city prospered from increased trade across the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic</a> supported by Dutch shipping. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christoffer_Valkendorff&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christoffer Valkendorff (page does not exist)">Christoffer Valkendorff</a>, a high-ranking statesman, defended the city's interests and contributed to its development.<sup id="cite_ref-khdsd_4-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-khdsd-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the reign of <a href="/wiki/Christian_IV_of_Denmark" title="Christian IV of Denmark">Christian IV</a> between 1588 and 1648, Copenhagen experienced dramatic growth as a city. On his initiative at the beginning of the 17th century, two important building were completed on Slotsholmen: the  <a href="/w/index.php?title=T%C3%B8jhus_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tøjhus Museum (page does not exist)">Tøjhus Arsenal</a> and <a href="/wiki/B%C3%B8rsen" title="Børsen">Børsen</a>, the stock exchange. To foster international trade, the <a href="/wiki/Danish_East_India_Company" title="Danish East India Company">East India Company</a> was founded in 1616. To the east of the city, inspired by Dutch planning, the king developed the district of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christianshavn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christianshavn (page does not exist)">Christianshavn</a> with its canals and ramparts. It was initially intended to be a fortified trading centre but ultimately became part of Copenhagen.<sup id="cite_ref-kher_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kher-10">[10]</a></sup> Christian IV was also responsible for sponsoring an array of ambitious building projects including <a href="/wiki/Rosenborg_Slot" title="Rosenborg Slot" class="mw-redirect">Rosenborg Slot</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rundetarn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rundetarn (page does not exist)">Rundetarn</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In 1658–59, the city withstood a siege by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweden (page does not exist)">Swedes</a> under <a href="/wiki/Charles_X_Gustav_of_Sweden" title="Charles X Gustav of Sweden">Charles X</a> and successfully repelled <a href="/w/index.php?title=Assault_on_Copenhagen_(1659)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Assault on Copenhagen (1659) (page does not exist)">a major assault</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-kher_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kher-10">[10]</a></sup>
</p><p>By 1661, Copenhagen had asserted its position as capital of Denmark and Norway. All the major institutions were located there as was the fleet and most of the army. The defences were further enhanced with the completion of the <a href="/wiki/Kastellet,_Copenhagen" title="Kastellet, Copenhagen">Citadel</a> in 1664 and the extension of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christianshavns_Vold&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christianshavns Vold (page does not exist)">Christianshavns Vold</a> with its bastions in 1692, leading to the creation of a new base for the fleet at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Holmen,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Holmen, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Nyholm</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-kher_10-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kher-10">[10]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="18th_century">18th century</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kbh_amalienborg_mpazdziora.jpg" title="File:Kbh amalienborg mpazdziora.jpg">File:Kbh amalienborg mpazdziora.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Amalienborg Palace in Frederiksstaden (1750)</div></div></div>
<p>In 1711 the <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_plague_during_the_Great_Northern_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The plague during the Great Northern War (page does not exist)">plague</a> reduced Copenhagen's population of about 65,000 by one-third.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The city was also struck by two major fires which destroyed much of the city's infrastructure.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Fire_of_1728&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Fire of 1728 (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Fire of 1728</a> was the largest in the history of Copenhagen. It began on the evening of 20 October, and continued to burn until the morning of 23 October, destroying approximately 28% of the city, leaving some 20% of the population homeless. No less than 47% of the medieval section of the city was completely lost. Along with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_fire_of_1795&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen fire of 1795 (page does not exist)">1795 fire</a>, it is the main reason that few traces of the old town can be found in the modern city.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p>A substantial amount of rebuilding followed. In 1733, work began on the royal residence of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christiansborg_Palace_(1st)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christiansborg Palace (1st) (page does not exist)">Christiansborg Palace</a> which was completed in 1745. In 1749, development of the prestigious district of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederiksstaden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederiksstaden (page does not exist)">Frederiksstaden</a> was initiated. Designed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nicolai_Eigtved&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nicolai Eigtved (page does not exist)">Nicolai Eigtved</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Rococo" title="Rococo">Rococo</a> style, its centre contained the mansions which now form <a href="/wiki/Amalienborg" title="Amalienborg">Amalienborg Palace</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> Major extensions to the naval base of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Holmen_naval_base&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Holmen naval base (page does not exist)">Holmen</a> were undertaken while the city's cultural importance was enhanced with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Danish_Theatre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Danish Theatre (page does not exist)">Royal Theatre</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Danish_Academy_of_Fine_Arts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts (page does not exist)">Royal Academy of Fine Arts</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-K.C3.B8benhavns_historie_1728-1914_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-K.C3.B8benhavns_historie_1728-1914-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the second half of the 18th century, Copenhagen benefitted from Denmark's neutrality during the wars between Europe's main powers, allowing it to play an important role in trade between the states around the Baltic Sea. After Christiansborg was destroyed by fire in 1794 and another fire caused serious damage to the city in 1795, work began on the classical Copenhagen landmark of <a href="/w/index.php?title=H%C3%B8jbro_Plads&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Højbro Plads (page does not exist)">Højbro Plads</a> while <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nytorv&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nytorv (page does not exist)">Nytorv</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gammel_Torv&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gammel Torv (page does not exist)">Gammel Torv</a> were converged.<sup id="cite_ref-K.C3.B8benhavns_historie_1728-1914_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-K.C3.B8benhavns_historie_1728-1914-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="19th_century">19th century</span></h3>
<p>On 2 April 1801, a <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">British</a> fleet under the command of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hyde_Parker_(admiral)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hyde Parker (admiral) (page does not exist)">Admiral Sir Hyde Parker</a> defeated a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Denmark%E2%80%93Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Denmark–Norway (page does not exist)">Danish-Norwegian</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Dano-Norwegian_Navy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Dano-Norwegian Navy (page does not exist)">fleet</a> anchored near Copenhagen. Vice-Admiral <a href="/w/index.php?title=Horatio_Nelson,_1st_Viscount_Nelson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson (page does not exist)">Horatio Nelson</a> led the main attack.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> He famously disobeyed Parker's order to withdraw, destroying many of the Dano-Norwegian ships before a truce was agreed.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Copenhagen is often considered to be Nelson's hardest-fought battle, surpassing even the heavy fighting at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Trafalgar" title="Battle of Trafalgar">Trafalgar</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> It was during this battle that Lord Nelson famously "put the telescope to the blind eye" in order not to see Admiral Parker's signal to <a href="/wiki/Ceasefire" title="Ceasefire">cease fire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-TimesOnline_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TimesOnline-16">[16]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Thoraldsens_Museum.jpg" title="File:Thoraldsens Museum.jpg">File:Thoraldsens Museum.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Gottlieb Bindesbøll's Thorvaldsen's Museum (1848)</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Copenhagen_(1807)" title="Battle of Copenhagen (1807)">Second Battle of Copenhagen</a> (or the Bombardment of Copenhagen) (16 August – 5 September 1807) was from a British point of view a <a href="/wiki/Preemptive_war" title="Preemptive war">preemptive attack</a> on Copenhagen, targeting the civilian population in order to seize the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Dano-Norwegian_Navy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Dano-Norwegian Navy (page does not exist)">Dano-Norwegian fleet</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> But from a Danish point of view the battle was a terror bombardment on their capital. Particularly notable was the use of incendiary <a href="/wiki/Congreve_rocket" title="Congreve rocket">Congreve rockets</a> (containing phosphorus, which cannot be extinguished with water) that randomly hit the city. Few houses with straw roofs remained after the bombardment. The largest church, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Church_of_Our_Lady_(Copenhagen)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Church of Our Lady (Copenhagen) (page does not exist)">Vor frue kirke</a></i>, was destroyed by the sea artillery. Several historians consider this battle the first <a href="/wiki/Terrorism" title="Terrorism">terror attack</a> against a major European city in modern times.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:KBH_1890-1900.jpg" title="File:KBH 1890-1900.jpg">File:KBH 1890-1900.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Slotsholmen" title="Slotsholmen">Slotsholmen</a> canal, as seen from <a href="/wiki/B%C3%B8rsen" title="Børsen">Børsen</a> (1890–1900). In the background from left to right: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Church_of_the_Holy_Ghost,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Church of the Holy Ghost, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Church of the Holy Ghost</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rundet%C3%A5rn" title="Rundetårn">Rundetårn</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trinitatis_Church&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trinitatis Church (page does not exist)">Trinity Church</a>, St. Nicholas Church (before the spire was rebuilt) and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Church_of_Holmen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Church of Holmen (page does not exist)">Holmen Church</a></div></div></div> The British landed 30,000 men and surrounded Copenhagen.<sup id="cite_ref-TimesOnline_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TimesOnline-16">[16]</a></sup> The attack continued for the next three days, killing some 2,000 civilians and destroying most of the city.<sup id="cite_ref-TimesOnline_16-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TimesOnline-16">[16]</a></sup> The devastation was so great because Copenhagen relied on an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fortifications_of_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fortifications of Copenhagen (page does not exist)">old defence-line</a> whose limited range could not reach the British ships and their <a href="/w/index.php?title=Range_of_a_projectile&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Range of a projectile (page does not exist)">longer-range</a> artillery.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
<p>Despite the disasters of the early 19th century, Copenhagen experienced a period of intense cultural creativity known as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_Golden_Age&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish Golden Age (page does not exist)">Danish Golden Age</a>. Painting prospered under <a href="/w/index.php?title=C.W._Eckersberg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="C.W. Eckersberg (page does not exist)">C.W. Eckersberg</a> and his students while <a href="/w/index.php?title=C.F._Hansen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="C.F. Hansen (page does not exist)">C.F. Hansen</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gottlieb_Bindesb%C3%B8ll&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gottlieb Bindesbøll (page does not exist)">Gottlieb Bindesbøll</a> brought a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Neoclassical_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Neoclassical architecture (page does not exist)">Neoclassical</a> look to the city's architecture.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> In the early 1850s, the ramparts of the city were opened to allow new housing to be built around <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Lakes,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Lakes, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">The Lakes</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-da&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-da (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-da</a>) that bordered the old defences to the west. By the 1880s, the districts of <a href="/w/index.php?title=N%C3%B8rrebro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nørrebro (page does not exist)">Nørrebro</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vesterbro,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vesterbro, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Vesterbro</a> developed to accommodate those who came from the provinces to participate in the city's industrialization. This dramatic increase of space was long overdue, as not only were the old ramparts out of date as a defence system but bad <a href="/wiki/Sanitation" title="Sanitation">sanitation</a> in the old city had to be overcome. From 1886, the west rampart (Vestvolden) was flattened, allowing major extensions to the harbour leading to the establishment of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Freeport_of_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Freeport of Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Freeport of Copenhagen</a> 1892–94.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup>  Electricity came in 1892 with electric trams in 1897. The spread of housing to areas outside the old ramparts brought about a huge increase in the population. In 1840, Copenhagen was inhabited by approximately 120,000 people. By 1901, it had some 400,000 inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-K.C3.B8benhavns_historie_1728-1914_15-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-K.C3.B8benhavns_historie_1728-1914-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="20th_century">20th century</span></h3>
<p>By the beginning of the 20th century, Copenhagen had become a thriving industrial and administrative city. With its new <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_City_Hall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen City Hall (page does not exist)">city hall</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Central_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Central Station (page does not exist)">railway station</a>, its centre was drawn towards the west.<sup id="cite_ref-K.C3.B8benhavns_historie_1728-1914_15-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-K.C3.B8benhavns_historie_1728-1914-15">[15]</a></sup> New housing developments grew up in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Br%C3%B8nsh%C3%B8j&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brønshøj (page does not exist)">Brønshøj</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Valby&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Valby (page does not exist)">Valby</a> while <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederiksberg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederiksberg (page does not exist)">Frederiksberg</a> became an enclave within the city of Copenhagen.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> The northern part of <a href="/wiki/Amager" title="Amager">Amager</a> and Valby were also incorporated into the City of Copenhagen in 1901–02.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup>
</p><p>As a result of Denmark's neutrality in the <a href="/wiki/First_World_War" title="First World War" class="mw-redirect">First World War</a>, Copenhagen prospered from trade with both Britain and Germany while the city's defences were kept fully manned by some 40,000 soldiers for the duration of the war.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 1920s there were serious shortages of goods and housing. Plans were drawn up to demolish the old part of Christianshavn and to get rid of the worst of the city's slum areas.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> However, it was not until the 1930s that substantial housing developments ensued,<sup id="cite_ref-K.C3.B8benhavns_historie_siden_1914_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-K.C3.B8benhavns_historie_siden_1914-24">[24]</a></sup> with the demolishment of one side of Christianhavn's  <a href="/w/index.php?title=Torvegade&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Torvegade (page does not exist)">Torvegade</a> in order to build five large blocks of flats.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<dl>
<dt>World War II</dt>
<dd>
</dd>
</dl>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Shellhuset_210345.jpg" title="File:Shellhuset 210345.jpg">File:Shellhuset 210345.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">RAF bombing of Gestapo headquarters in the Shell House (March 1945)</div></div></div> 
<p>During <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, Copenhagen was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Occupation of Denmark (page does not exist)">occupied by German troops</a> along with the rest of the country from 9 April 1940 until 4 May 1945. The occupation was not a part of the Nazi German expansion, and initially the German authorities sought to arrive at an understanding with the Danish government. Even a general parliamentary election was granted in 1943, with only the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Denmark" title="Communist Party of Denmark">Communist Party</a> excluded. But in August 1943, after the government's collaboration with the occupation forces collapsed, several ships were <a href="/wiki/Scuttling" title="Scuttling">scuttled</a> in Copenhagen Harbour by the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Danish_Navy" title="Royal Danish Navy">Royal Danish Navy</a> to prevent their use by the Germans. Around that time the Nazis <a href="/wiki/Racial_policy_of_Nazi_Germany" title="Racial policy of Nazi Germany">started to arrest Jews</a>, although most managed to escape to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweden (page does not exist)">Sweden</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-occupation_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-occupation-25">[25]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Normandy" title="Invasion of Normandy">Normandy Invasion</a> the Germans feared the Danish police could become a problem. In early September 1944, they set about arresting the entire Danish police force. Most of them, however, managed either to hide or to escape to Sweden. Out of 2,000 policemen captured and deported to Germany, fewer than half returned after the war. In the absence of a police force, during the last eight months of occupation Copenhagen suffered a high rate of common criminality.<sup id="cite_ref-occupation_25-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-occupation-25">[25]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ole Lippman, the leader of the <a href="/wiki/Special_Operations_Executive" title="Special Operations Executive">Danish resistance movement (SOE)</a>, invited the <a href="/w/index.php?title=RAF&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="RAF (page does not exist)">RAF</a> to assist their operations by attacking Nazi headquarters in Copenhagen. Accordingly, <a href="/wiki/Air_vice-marshal" title="Air vice-marshal">Air Vice-Marshal</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Basil_Embry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Basil Embry (page does not exist)">Sir Basil Embry</a> drew up plans for a spectacular precision attack on the <a href="/wiki/Sicherheitsdienst" title="Sicherheitsdienst">Sicherheitsdienst</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gestapo" title="Gestapo">Gestapo</a> building, the former offices of the <a href="/wiki/Shell_Oil_Company" title="Shell Oil Company">Shell Oil Company</a>. Political prisoners were kept in the attic to prevent an air raid, so the RAF had to bomb the lower levels of the building. The attack came on 22 March 1945, in three small waves. In the first wave, all six planes (carrying one bomb each) hit their target, but unfortunately one of the aircraft crashed near Frederiksberg girls school. Because of this crash four of the planes in the two following waves assumed the school was the military target, and aimed their bombs at the school leading to the death of 123 civilians (of which 87 were schoolgirls).<sup id="cite_ref-milhist.dk_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milhist.dk-26">[26]</a></sup> However 18 of the 26 political prisoners in the Shell Building managed to escape while the Gestapo archives were completely destroyed.<sup id="cite_ref-milhist.dk_26-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milhist.dk-26">[26]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl>
<dt>Post-war decades</dt>
<dd>
</dd>
</dl>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:SHL_-_Black_Diamond.jpg" title="File:SHL - Black Diamond.jpg">File:SHL - Black Diamond.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Black Diamond (1999)</div></div></div>
<p>Shortly after the end of the war, an innovative urban development project known as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Finger_Plan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Finger Plan (page does not exist)">Finger Plan</a> was introduced in 1947, encouraging the creation of new housing and businesses interspersed with large green areas along five "fingers" stretching out from the city centre along the <a href="/wiki/S-train" title="S-train">S-train</a> routes.<sup id="cite_ref-OECD2010_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD2010-27">[27]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> With the expansion of the welfare state and women entering the work force, schools, nurseries, sports facilities and hospitals were established across the city. As a result of student unrest in the late 1960s, the former Bådsmandsstræde Barracks in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christianshavn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christianshavn (page does not exist)">Christianshavn</a> was occupied, leading to the establishment of <a href="/wiki/Freetown_Christiania" title="Freetown Christiania">Freetown Christiania</a> in September 1971.<sup id="cite_ref-kkkh_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kkkh-28">[28]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bridge_over_%C3%98resund.jpg" title="File:Bridge over Øresund.jpg">File:Bridge over Øresund.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Øresund Bridge (1999)</div></div></div>
<p>Motor traffic in the city grew significantly and in 1972 the trams were replaced by buses. From the 1960s, on the initiative of the young architect <a href="/wiki/Jan_Gehl" title="Jan Gehl">Jan Gehl</a>, pedestrian streets and cycle tracks were created in the city centre.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> Activity in the port of Copenhagen declined with the closure of the Holmen naval base. <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Airport" title="Copenhagen Airport">Copenhagen Airport</a> underwent considerable expansion, becoming a hub for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nordic_countries&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nordic countries (page does not exist)">Nordic countries</a>. In the 1990s, large-scale housing developments were realized in the harbour area and in the west of <a href="/wiki/Amager" title="Amager">Amager</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-K.C3.B8benhavns_historie_siden_1914_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-K.C3.B8benhavns_historie_siden_1914-24">[24]</a></sup> The national library's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Black_Diamond_(library)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Black Diamond (library) (page does not exist)">Black Diamond</a> building on the waterfront was completed in 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2000_to_present">2000 to present</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Copenaghen_Opera_House.jpg" title="File:Copenaghen Opera House.jpg">File:Copenaghen Opera House.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Copenhagen Opera House (2004)</div></div></div>
<p>Since the summer of 2000, Copenhagen and the Swedish city of <a href="/wiki/Malm%C3%B6" title="Malmö">Malmö</a> have been connected by the (<a href="/wiki/%C3%98resund_Bridge" title="Øresund Bridge">Øresund Bridge</a>), which carries rail and road traffic. As a result, Copenhagen has become the centre of a larger metropolitan area spanning both nations. The bridge has brought about considerable changes in the public <a href="/wiki/Transport_network" title="Transport network">transport system</a> and has led to the extensive redevelopment of Amager.<sup id="cite_ref-kkkh_28-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kkkh-28">[28]</a></sup> The city's service and trade sectors have developed while a number of banking and financial institutions have been established. Educational institutions have also gained importance, especially the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Copenhagen" title="University of Copenhagen">University of Copenhagen</a> with its 35,000 students.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> Another important development for the city has been the <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Metro" title="Copenhagen Metro">Copenhagen Metro</a>, the underground railway system which opened in 2000 with additions until 2007, transporting some 54 million passengers by 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup>
</p><p>On the cultural front, the lavish <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Opera_House&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Opera House (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Opera House</a>, a gift to the city from the shipping magnate <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A6rsk_Mc-Kinney_M%C3%B8ller" title="Mærsk Mc-Kinney Møller">Mærsk Mc-Kinney Møller</a> on behalf of the A.P. Møller foundation, was completed in 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> In December 2009 Copenhagen gained international prominence when it hosted the worldwide climate meeting <a href="/w/index.php?title=COP15&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="COP15 (page does not exist)">COP15</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Clear_all&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Clear all (page does not exist)">Template:Clear all</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Copenhagen_skyline.jpg" title="File:Copenhagen skyline.jpg">File:Copenhagen skyline.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Skyline of the old city core of Copenhagen.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Copenhagen_12.57744E_55.66605N.jpg" title="File:Copenhagen 12.57744E 55.66605N.jpg">File:Copenhagen 12.57744E 55.66605N.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Satellite view</div></div></div>
<p>Copenhagen is part of the <a href="/wiki/%C3%98resund_Region" title="Øresund Region">Øresund Region</a>, which consists of Zealand, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lolland-Falster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lolland-Falster (page does not exist)">Lolland-Falster</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bornholm" title="Bornholm">Bornholm</a> in Denmark and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scania (page does not exist)">Scania</a> in Sweden.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> It is located on the eastern shore of the island of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Zealand_(Denmark)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zealand (Denmark) (page does not exist)">Zealand</a>, partly on the island of <a href="/wiki/Amager" title="Amager">Amager</a> and on a number of natural and artificial islets between the two. Copenhagen faces the <a href="/wiki/%C3%98resund" title="Øresund">Øresund</a> to the east, the strait of water that separates Denmark from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweden (page does not exist)">Sweden</a>, and which connects the <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">North Sea</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweden (page does not exist)">Swedish</a> towns of <a href="/wiki/Malm%C3%B6" title="Malmö">Malmö</a> and <a href="/wiki/Landskrona" title="Landskrona">Landskrona</a> lie on the Swedish side of the sound directly across from Copenhagen.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> By road, Copenhagen is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> northwest of <a href="/wiki/Malm%C3%B6" title="Malmö">Malmö</a>, Sweden, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> northeast of <a href="/w/index.php?title=N%C3%A6stved&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Næstved (page does not exist)">Næstved</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> northeast of <a href="/wiki/Odense" title="Odense">Odense</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> east of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Esbjerg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Esbjerg (page does not exist)">Esbjerg</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> southeast of <a href="/wiki/Aarhus" title="Aarhus">Aarhus</a> by sea and road via <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sjaellands_Odde&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sjaellands Odde (page does not exist)">Sjaellands Odde</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city centre lies in the area originally defined by the old ramparts that are still referred to as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fortification_Ring,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fortification Ring, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Fortification Ring</a> (<i>Fæstningsringen</i>) and kept as a partial green band around it.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup>  Then come the late 19th and early 20th century residential neighbourhoods of <a href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%98sterbro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Østerbro (page does not exist)">Østerbro</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=N%C3%B8rrebro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nørrebro (page does not exist)">Nørrebro</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vesterbro,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vesterbro, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Vesterbro</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amagerbro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amagerbro (page does not exist)">Amagerbro</a>. The outlying areas of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kongens_Enghave&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kongens Enghave (page does not exist)">Kongens Enghave</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Valby&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Valby (page does not exist)">Valby</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vigerslev&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vigerslev (page does not exist)">Vigerslev</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vanl%C3%B8se&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vanløse (page does not exist)">Vanløse</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Br%C3%B8nsh%C3%B8j&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brønshøj (page does not exist)">Brønshøj</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Utterslev&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Utterslev (page does not exist)">Utterslev</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sundby,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sundby, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Sundby</a> followed from 1920 to 1960. They consist mainly of residential housing and apartments often enhanced with parks and greenery.<sup id="cite_ref-kgdsd_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kgdsd-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Topography">Topography</span></h3>
<p>The central area of the city consists of relatively low-lying flat ground formed by <a href="/wiki/Moraine" title="Moraine">moraines</a> from the last ice age while the hilly areas to the north and west frequently rise to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> above sea level. The slopes of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Valby&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Valby (page does not exist)">Valby</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Br%C3%B8nsh%C3%B8j&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brønshøj (page does not exist)">Brønshøj</a> reach heights of over <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, divided by valleys running from the northeast to the southwest. Close to the centre are the <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Lakes,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Lakes, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Copenhagen lakes</a> of Sortedams Sø, Peblinge Sø and Sankt Jørgens Sø.<sup id="cite_ref-kgdsd_39-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kgdsd-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>Copenhagen rests on a subsoil of flint-layered limestone deposited in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danian (page does not exist)">Danian</a> period some 60 to 66 million years ago. Some <a href="/wiki/Greensand" title="Greensand">greensand</a> from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Selandian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Selandian (page does not exist)">Selandian</a> is also present. There are a few faults in the area, the most important of which is the Carlsberg fault which runs northwest to southeast through the centre of the city.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> During the last ice age, glaciers eroded the surface leaving a layer of moraines up to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> thick.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Beaches">Beaches</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Amager_Strandpark_-_kite_surfers.jpg" title="File:Amager Strandpark - kite surfers.jpg">File:Amager Strandpark - kite surfers.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Amager_Strandpark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amager Strandpark (page does not exist)">Amager Strandpark</a></div></div></div>
<p>Copenhagen and the surrounding areas have three beaches with a total of approx. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of sandy shores within 30 minutes cycling from the city centre. These include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amager_Strandpark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amager Strandpark (page does not exist)">Amager Strandpark</a>, which opened in 2005 with a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> long artificial island and a total of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of beaches, located just 15 minutes by bicycle or a few minutes by metro from the city centre.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup>
</p><p>The beaches are supplemented by a system of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Harbour_Baths&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Harbour Baths (page does not exist)">Harbour Baths</a> along the Copenhagen waterfront. The first and most popular of these is located at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Islands_Brygge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Islands Brygge (page does not exist)">Islands Brygge</a> and has won international acclaim for its design.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Frederiksberg_Palace_from_above_(winter).JPG" title="File:Frederiksberg Palace from above (winter).JPG">File:Frederiksberg Palace from above (winter).JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Frederiksberg Palace in the snow</div></div></div>
<p>Copenhagen is in the <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic climate</a> zone (<a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen</a>: <i>Cfb&#x202f;</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> Its weather is subject to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Low_pressure_area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Low pressure area (page does not exist)">low-pressure systems</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic</a> which result in unstable conditions throughout the year. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gulf_Stream&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gulf Stream (page does not exist)">Gulf Stream</a> brings warmer water across from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gulf_of_Mexico&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gulf of Mexico (page does not exist)">Gulf of Mexico</a> causing average temperatures to be some 5 degrees higher than would be expected for the city's latitude of 55 degrees North. Apart from slightly higher rainfall from July to September, precipitation is moderate. While there can be snow from late December to early March, there can also be rain with average temperatures around the freezing point.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>June is the sunniest month of the year with an average of about eight hours of sunshine a day. July and August are warm too with daytime temperatures around <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> although rainfall averages 69&#160;mm per month. By contrast, the average hours of sunshine are less than two per day in November and only one and a half per day from December to February. In the spring, it gets warmer again with from four to six hours of sunshine per day from March to May. February is the driest month of the year.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> Exceptional weather conditions can bring as much as 50&#160;cm of snow to Copenhagen in a 24 hour period during the winter months<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> while summer temperatures have been known to rise to heights of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> (91°F).<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p><p>Because of Copenhagen's northern latitude, the number of daylight hours varies considerably between summer and winter. In mid-summer, the sun rises at 4.26 am and sets at 9.58 pm, providing 17 hours 32 minutes of daylight. In mid-winter, it rises at 8.37 am and sets at 15.39 pm with 7 hours and 1 minute of daylight. There is therefore a difference of 10 hours and 31 minutes in the length of days and nights between the summer and winter solstices .<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Weather_box&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Weather box (page does not exist)">Template:Weather box</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Administration">Administration</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Districts">Districts</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Districts_of_Copenhagen_urban_area.jpg" title="File:Districts of Copenhagen urban area.jpg">File:Districts of Copenhagen urban area.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Districts of Copenhagen municipality</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Conurbation" title="Conurbation">conurbation</a> of Copenhagen includes the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Municipalities_of_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Municipalities of Denmark (page does not exist)">municipalities</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Municipality&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Municipality (page does not exist)">Copenhagen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Drag%C3%B8r_Municipality" title="Dragør Municipality">Dragør</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frederiksberg_Municipality" title="Frederiksberg Municipality">Frederiksberg</a> and <a href="/wiki/T%C3%A5rnby_Municipality" title="Tårnby Municipality">Tårnby</a>, with a total population of 704,108 at the start of 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-StatDen_Pop_080101_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-StatDen_Pop_080101-50">[50]</a></sup> After <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Municipality&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Municipality (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Municipality</a>, the second largest is Frederiksberg Municipality, an enclave inside Copenhagen Municipality. Both are contained in the larger <a href="/w/index.php?title=Capital_Region_of_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Capital Region of Denmark (page does not exist)">Capital Region of Denmark</a>, containing most of the <a href="/wiki/Urban_area_of_Copenhagen" title="Urban area of Copenhagen">urban area of Copenhagen</a>. 
Since a reform in 2006–08, Copenhagen Municipality has been divided into 10 official districts (Danish: bydele):<sup id="cite_ref-K.C3.B8benhavns_bydele_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-K.C3.B8benhavns_bydele-51">[51]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indre_By&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indre By (page does not exist)">Indre By</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%98sterbro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Østerbro (page does not exist)">Østerbro</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=N%C3%B8rrebro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nørrebro (page does not exist)">Nørrebro</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vesterbro/Kongens_Enghave&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vesterbro/Kongens Enghave (page does not exist)">Vesterbro/Kongens Enghave</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Valby&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Valby (page does not exist)">Valby</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vanl%C3%B8se&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vanløse (page does not exist)">Vanløse</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Br%C3%B8nsh%C3%B8j-Husum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brønshøj-Husum (page does not exist)">Brønshøj-Husum</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bispebjerg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bispebjerg (page does not exist)">Bispebjerg</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amager_%C3%98st&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amager Øst (page does not exist)">Amager Øst</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amager_Vest&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amager Vest (page does not exist)">Amager Vest</a>. Neighbourhoods of Copenhagen include <a href="/wiki/Slotsholmen" title="Slotsholmen">Slotsholmen</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederiksstaden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederiksstaden (page does not exist)">Frederiksstaden</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Islands_Brygge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Islands Brygge (page does not exist)">Islands Brygge</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Holmen,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Holmen, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Holmen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freetown_Christiania" title="Freetown Christiania">Christiania</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carlsberg_(district)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carlsberg (district) (page does not exist)">Carlsberg</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sluseholmen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sluseholmen (page does not exist)">Sluseholmen</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amagerbro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amagerbro (page does not exist)">Amagerbro</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%98restad&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ørestad (page does not exist)">Ørestad</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nordhavnen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nordhavnen (page does not exist)">Nordhavnen</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bellah%C3%B8j&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bellahøj (page does not exist)">Bellahøj</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Br%C3%B8nsh%C3%B8j&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brønshøj (page does not exist)">Brønshøj</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ryparken&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ryparken (page does not exist)">Ryparken</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vigerslev&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vigerslev (page does not exist)">Vigerslev</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Municipal_government">Municipal government</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Copenhagen_City_Hall.jpg" title="File:Copenhagen City Hall.jpg">File:Copenhagen City Hall.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_City_Hall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen City Hall (page does not exist)">Copenhagen City Hall</a></div></div></div>
<p>The seat of Copenhagen's municipal council (Borgerrepræsentation) is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_City_Hall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen City Hall (page does not exist)">Copenhagen City Hall</a> (<i>Københavns Rådhus</i>). The council is chaired by the Lord Mayor of Copenhagen, <a href="/wiki/Frank_Jensen" title="Frank Jensen">Frank Jensen</a>, who with two selected vice-presidents overlooks the 55 representatives of the council who are given civic duties to perform.<sup id="cite_ref-kborg_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kborg-52">[52]</a></sup> The council usually meets every other week at 17:30 on a Thursday.<sup id="cite_ref-kborg_52-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kborg-52">[52]</a></sup>
They discuss a range of issues including labour and employment, business growth, economics, international cooperation and IT, urban planning, housing and construction, and young, old, and disabled people issues, healthcare, and traffic, with a central focus on making the city sustainable and meeting environmental and health targets.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> 
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Frank_Jensen_Bogforum10.jpg" title="File:Frank Jensen Bogforum10.jpg">File:Frank Jensen Bogforum10.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Mayor <a href="/wiki/Frank_Jensen" title="Frank Jensen">Frank Jensen</a></div></div></div>
<p>All members of the council are elected every four years. In the municipal elections in November 2013, the <a href="/wiki/Social_Democrats_(Denmark)" title="Social Democrats (Denmark)">Social Democrats</a> remained in first place with 27.8% of the vote (down by 2.2% from 2009) while Enhedslisten (the Red-Green Alliance) was in second place with 19.5%.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> Copenhagen's mayor Frank Jensen retained his position, but was not happy with the result which was the worst ever for his party. The Social Democrats have been the party behind the mayors of Copenhagen for the past 110 years.<sup id="cite_ref-ritzau_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ritzau-56">[56]</a></sup>
</p><p>The municipal government is divided into seven administrative departments; Employment and Integration, Culture and Leisure, Health and Care, Finance, Child and Youth, Social Services, and Technical and Environmental Administration.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> It has six political committees and a finance committee. The annual budget for the city is proposed in August and finalized in October and the annual report is published in May of every year. The accounting firm <a href="/wiki/Deloitte" title="Deloitte">Deloitte</a> is responsible for auditing the City of Copenhagen's accounts.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Lord_mayors_since_1938">Lord mayors since 1938</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
All lord mayors of Copenhagen have belonged to <a href="/wiki/Socialdemokraterne" title="Socialdemokraterne" class="mw-redirect">the Social Democratic Party</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ritzau_56-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ritzau-56">[56]</a></sup>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Div_col&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Div col (page does not exist)">Template:Div col</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li>1938–1946: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Viggo_Christensen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Viggo Christensen (page does not exist)">Viggo Christensen</a>
</li>
<li>1946–1956: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hans_Peter_S%C3%B8rensen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hans Peter Sørensen (page does not exist)">Hans Peter Sørensen</a>
</li>
<li>1956–1962: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sigvard_Munk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sigvard Munk (page does not exist)">Sigvard Munk</a>
</li>
<li>1962–1976: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Urban_Hansen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Urban Hansen (page does not exist)">Urban Hansen</a>
</li>
<li>1976–1989: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Egon_Weidekamp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Egon Weidekamp (page does not exist)">Egon Weidekamp</a>
</li>
<li>1989–2004: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jens_Kramer_Mikkelsen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jens Kramer Mikkelsen (page does not exist)">Jens Kramer Mikkelsen</a>
</li>
