<li>2004–2005: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lars_Engberg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lars Engberg (page does not exist)">Lars Engberg</a>
</li>
<li>2006–2009: <a href="/wiki/Ritt_Bjerregaard" title="Ritt Bjerregaard">Ritt Bjerregaard</a>
</li>
<li>2010-   &#160;: <a href="/wiki/Frank_Jensen" title="Frank Jensen">Frank Jensen</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Div_col_end&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Div col end (page does not exist)">Template:Div col end</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_and_order">Law and order</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Copenhagen_Court_House.jpg" title="File:Copenhagen Court House.jpg">File:Copenhagen Court House.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Court_House&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Court House (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Court House</a></div></div></div>
<p>Most of Denmark's top legal courts and institutions are based in Copenhagen. A modern style <a href="/wiki/Court" title="Court">court of justice</a>, <i>Hof- og Stadsretten</i>, was introduced in Denmark, specifically for Copenhagen, by <a href="/wiki/Johann_Friedrich_Struensee" title="Johann Friedrich Struensee">Johann Friedrich Struensee</a> in 1771.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> Now known as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Court_House&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Court House (page does not exist)">City Court of Copenhagen</a> (<i>Kobenhavns Byret</i>), it is the largest of the 24 city courts in Denmark with jurisdiction over the municipalities of Copenhagen, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Drag%C3%B8r&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dragør (page does not exist)">Dragør</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=T%C3%A5rnby&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tårnby (page does not exist)">Tårnby</a>. With its 42 judges, it has a Probate Division, an Enforcement Division and a Registration and Notorial Acts Division while bankruptcy is handled by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maritime_and_Commercial_Court_(Denmark)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maritime and Commercial Court (Denmark) (page does not exist)">Maritime and Commercial Court of Copenhagen</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> Established in 1862, the Maritime and Commercial Court (<i>Sø- og Handelsretten</i>) also hears commercial cases including those relating to trade marks, marketing practices and competition for the whole of Denmark.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> Denmark's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Supreme Court of Denmark (page does not exist)">Supreme Court</a> (<i>Højesteret</i>, located in <a href="/wiki/Christiansborg_Palace" title="Christiansborg Palace">Christiansborg Palace</a> on Prins Jørgens Gård in the centre of Copenhagen, is the country's final court of appeal. Handling civil and criminal cases from the subordinate courts, it has two chambers which each hear all types of cases.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Police_HQ_Copenhagen.JPG" title="File:Police HQ Copenhagen.JPG">File:Police HQ Copenhagen.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i>Politigården</i>, the police headquarters</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_National_Police&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish National Police (page does not exist)">Danish National Police</a> and Copenhagen Police headquarters is situated in the Neoclassical-inspired <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Police_Headquarters&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Police Headquarters (page does not exist)">Politigården</a> building built in 1918–24 under architects <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hack_Kampmann&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hack Kampmann (page does not exist)">Hack Kampmann</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Holger_Jacobsen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Holger Jacobsen (page does not exist)">Holger Alfred Jacobsen</a>. The building also contains administration, management, emergency department and radio service offices.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> In their efforts to deal with drugs, the police have noted considerable success in the two special drug consumption rooms opened by the city where addicts can use sterile needles and receive help from nurses if necessary. While drugs are still illegal, police do not prosecute addicts using the rooms. Deputy Chief Superintendent Kaj Majlund commented, "You have to find new ways to deal with drug addicts. You can't succeed by putting them into jail."<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Fire_Department&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Fire Department (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Fire Department</a> forms the largest municipal fire brigade in Denmark with some 500 fire and ambulance personnel, 150 administration and service workers, and 35 workers in prevention.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> The brigade began as the Copenhagen Royal Fire Brigade on 9 July 1687 under King Christian V. After the passing of the Copenhagen Fire Act on 18 May 1868, on 1 August 1870 the Copenhagen Fire Brigade became a municipal institution in its own right.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> The fire department has its headquarters in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Central_Fire_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Central Fire Station (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Central Fire Station</a> which was designed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ludvig_Fenger&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ludvig Fenger (page does not exist)">Ludvig Fenger</a> in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Historicism_(art)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Historicism (art) (page does not exist)">Historicist</a> style and inaugurated in 1892.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environmental_planning">Environmental planning</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Copenhagen_view_from_North_port_20090818_41.JPG" title="File:Copenhagen view from North port 20090818 41.JPG">File:Copenhagen view from North port 20090818 41.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Middelgrunden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Middelgrunden (page does not exist)">Middelgrunden</a> offshore wind farm</div></div></div>
<p>Copenhagen is recognized as one of the most environmentally friendly cities in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> 
The municipal policy is to reduce <a href="/w/index.php?title=Global_warming&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Global warming (page does not exist)">CO2 emissions</a> by 20% before the end of 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> In 2001 a large offshore <a href="/wiki/Wind_farm" title="Wind farm">wind farm</a> was built just off the coast of Copenhagen at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Middelgrunden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Middelgrunden (page does not exist)">Middelgrunden</a>. It produces about 4% of the city's energy.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> Years of substantial investment in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sewage_treatment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sewage treatment (page does not exist)">sewage treatment</a> have improved <a href="/wiki/Water_quality" title="Water quality">water quality</a> in the harbour to an extent that the inner harbour can be used for swimming with facilities at a number of locations.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p><p>Copenhagen aims to be carbon-neutral by 2025. Commercial and residential buildings are to reduce electricity consumption by 20 percent and 10 percent respectively, and total heat consumption is to fall by 20 percent by 2025. Renewable energy features such as solar panels are becoming increasingly common in the newest buildings in Copenhagen. District heating will be carbon-neutral by 2025. New buildings must now be constructed according to Low Energy Class ratings and in 2020 near net-zero energy buildings. By 2025, 75% of trips should be made on foot, by bike, or by using public transit. The city plans that 20-30% of cars will run on electricity or <a href="/wiki/Biofuel" title="Biofuel">biofuel</a> by 2025. The investment is estimated at $472 million public funds and $4.78 billion private funds.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city's architectural planning authorities continue to take full account of these priorities. Special attention is given both to climate issues and efforts to ensure maximum application of <a href="/wiki/Low-energy_house" title="Low-energy house">low-energy standards</a>. Priorities include <a href="/wiki/Water_conservation" title="Water conservation">recycling rainwater</a>, <a href="/wiki/Green_roof" title="Green roof">green roofs</a> and efficient <a href="/wiki/Waste_management" title="Waste management">waste management</a> solutions. In city planning, streets and squares are to be designed to encourage cycling and walking rather than driving.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup>
</p><p>As a result of its commitment to high environmental standards, Copenhagen has been praised for its <a href="/wiki/Green_economy" title="Green economy">green economy</a>, becoming the world's leading green city in the 2012 Global Green Economy Index.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> It has also received the title of "European Green Capital 2014" as a result of its environmental record and its ambitious goals. Mention was made of the city's efforts to work with companies, universities and organisations in order to further green growth, the "Green Laboratory" component in its North Harbour project, and its efforts to increase the proportion of the population cycling to work to 50% by 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics_and_society">Demographics and society</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Christiansborg,_Copenhagen.jpg" title="File:Christiansborg, Copenhagen.jpg">File:Christiansborg, Copenhagen.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Christiansborg_Palace" title="Christiansborg Palace">Christiansborg Palace</a> which seats the <a href="/wiki/Danish_Parliament" title="Danish Parliament" class="mw-redirect">Danish Parliament</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Denmark" title="Prime Minister of Denmark">Danish Prime Minister's Office</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Supreme Court of Denmark (page does not exist)">Danish Supreme Court</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Statistics from fourth quarter 2013 show that 439,824 (77.3%) of the population of Copenhagen Municipality were of <a href="/wiki/Danes" title="Danes">Danish origin</a>, 41,423 immigrants and 4,628 descendants from Western countries (8.1%), 56,026 immigrants and 27,099 descendants from non-Western countries (14.6%).<sup id="cite_ref-dstfolk1_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dstfolk1-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Population">Population</span></h3>
<p>Depending on the boundaries used, the population of Copenhagen differs. Statistics Denmark has never specified the geographical area of urban Copenhagen, but it is known to consist of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Municipality&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Municipality (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Municipality</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frederiksberg_Municipality" title="Frederiksberg Municipality">Frederiksberg</a> and 16 of the 20 municipalities in the old counties <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_County" title="Copenhagen County">Copenhagen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Roskilde_County" title="Roskilde County">Roskilde</a>, though five of them only partially.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> The urban area of Copenhagen has a population of 1,230,728 inhabitants as of 2013, with a total of 1,937,611 inhabitants in the overall metropolitan area as 2012; the latter is equivalent to the local traffic area and ticket fare zones, covering <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Based on a 10%-isoline (data from 2002) in which at least 10% of the population commutes into central parts of the Copenhagen area, most of Zealand would be covered and this area has a population of about 2.3&#160;million inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the opening of the Øresund Bridge in 2000, commuting between <a href="/wiki/Zealand" title="Zealand">Zealand</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scania (page does not exist)">Scania</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweden (page does not exist)">Sweden</a> has increased rapidly, leading to a wider, integrated area. Known as the Øresund Region, it has 3.8 million inhabitants (of which 2.5 million live in the Danish part of the region).<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The majority of those living in Copenhagen are members of the Lutheran <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Denmark" title="Church of Denmark">Church of Denmark</a>, although the 61.6% specifically confirming their membership by paying church taxes is well below the national average of 79.1% according to 2013 figures.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup> There are also several other Christian communities in the city, of which the largest is <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic" title="Roman Catholic" class="mw-redirect">Roman Catholic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup> The second most significant religion practised in the city is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Islam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Islam (page does not exist)">Islam</a>. While there are no official statistics, most of the estimated 150,000 Muslims in the country live in Copenhagen, with the highest concentration in <a href="/w/index.php?title=N%C3%B8rrebro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nørrebro (page does not exist)">Nørrebro</a> and the Vestegnen.<sup id="cite_ref-osf_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-osf-82">[82]</a></sup> There are some 7,000 <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Jews</a> in Denmark, most of them in the Copenhagen area where there are several synagogues.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Quality_of_living">Quality of living</span></h3>
<p>For a number of years, Copenhagen has ranked high in international surveys for its <a href="/wiki/Quality_of_life" title="Quality of life">quality of life</a>. Its stable economy together with its education services and level of social safety make it attractive for locals and visitors alike. Although it is one of the world's most expensive cities, it is also one of the most liveable with its public transport, facilities for cyclists and its environmental policies.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> In elevating Copenhagen to "most liveable city" in 2013, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Monocle_(media_company)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Monocle (media company) (page does not exist)">Monocle</a></i> pointed to its open spaces, increasing activity on the streets, city planning in favour of cyclists and pedestrians, and features to encourage inhabitants to enjoy city life with an emphasis on community, culture and cuisine.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> Other sources have ranked Copenhagen high for its business environment, accessibility, restaurants and environmental planning.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> For students, however, Copenhagen ranks only No. 39 for student friendliness in 2012. Despite a top score for quality of living, its scores were low for employer activity and affordability.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Copenhavn_port.jpg" title="File:Copenhavn port.jpg">File:Copenhavn port.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The port of Copenhagen</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ferring_Neroport_Orestad_20100810_0179F_(8370660268).jpg" title="File:Ferring Neroport Orestad 20100810 0179F (8370660268).jpg">File:Ferring Neroport Orestad 20100810 0179F (8370660268).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Scandinavian headquarters for the <a href="/wiki/Swiss" title="Swiss" class="mw-redirect">Swiss</a> pharmaceutical company <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ferring_Pharmaceuticals&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ferring Pharmaceuticals (page does not exist)">Ferring Pharmaceuticals</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Metro" title="Copenhagen Metro">metro</a> in front</div></div></div>
<p>Copenhagen is not only the economic and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Financial_centre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Financial centre (page does not exist)">financial centre</a> of <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a> but is a major business centre for the entire Scandinavian-Baltic region. Statistics for 2010 show that of the 350,000 people working in Copenhagen, the vast majority are employed in the <a href="/wiki/Service_sector" title="Service sector" class="mw-redirect">service sector</a>, especially transport and communications, trade, and finance, while less than 10,000 work in the <a href="/wiki/Manufacturing" title="Manufacturing">manufacturing industries</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Public_sector" title="Public sector">public sector</a> workforce is around 110,000, including education and healthcare.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup> From 2006 to 2011, the economy grew by 2.5% in Copenhagen and Copenhagen Municipality while it fell by some 4% in the rest of Denmark.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup>
</p><p>In <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dansk_Industri&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dansk Industri (page does not exist)">Dansk Industri</a>'s 2013 survey of employment factors in 96 Danish municipalities, Copenhagen came in first place for educational qualifications and for the development of private companies in recent years but fell to No. 86 in local companies' assessment of the employment climate. The survey revealed considerable dissatisfaction in the level of dialogue companies enjoyed with the municipal authorities.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> In 2012, Copenhagen was third in the ranking of the richest cities in the world in terms of gross earnings, dropping from first place in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> In the 2011 UBS survey of prices and earnings, Copenhagen had fallen to fifth place for price levels while it held third place in gross wage levels and was said to have the highest purchasing power in terms of gross hourly wages although it was only in 12th place in terms of domestic purchasing power.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup>
</p><p>Copenhagen is home to a number of international companies including <a href="/wiki/Maersk" title="Maersk">A.P. Møller-Mærsk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Novo_Nordisk" title="Novo Nordisk">Novo Nordisk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carlsberg_Group" title="Carlsberg Group">Carlsberg</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Novozymes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Novozymes (page does not exist)">Novozymes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup> The city also has successful business clusters in several innovative sectors including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Information_technology&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Information technology (page does not exist)">information technology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Biotechnology" title="Biotechnology">biotechnology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pharmaceuticals" title="Pharmaceuticals" class="mw-redirect">pharmaceuticals</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Clean_technology&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Clean technology (page does not exist)">clean technology</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup>
</p><p>Tourism is also an increasingly important sector for Copenhagen's economy, reaching record numbers in 2012 for the third year in succession. The number of room nights reached 8.1 million, up 25% since 2008. Between 2011 and 2012, room nights increased 9.2% overall, tallying a rise of 39% for Chinese visitors. The numbers of airline and cruise passengers visiting the city were also at new highs while turnover for congress tourism reached DKK 1.2 billion with a total of 57 congresses in the year.
<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup>
</p><p>Copenhagen has a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Service-orientation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Service-orientation (page does not exist)">service oriented</a> economy. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Biology&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Biology (page does not exist)">Life science</a> is a key sector with extensive <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">research and development</a> activities. In collaboration with Sweden, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Medicon_Valley&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Medicon Valley (page does not exist)">Medicon Valley</a> is being developed as a central sector of interest across the entire <a href="/wiki/%C3%98resund_Region" title="Øresund Region">Øresund Region</a>. Major Danish biotech companies like <a href="/wiki/Novo_Nordisk" title="Novo Nordisk">Novo Nordisk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lundbeck" title="Lundbeck">Lundbeck</a>, both of which are among the <a href="/wiki/List_of_pharmaceutical_companies" title="List of pharmaceutical companies">50 largest pharmaceutical and biotech companies in the world</a>, are located in the greater Copenhagen area.<sup id="cite_ref-usatoday_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-usatoday-96">[96]</a></sup> Shipping is also an import sector with <a href="/w/index.php?title=A._P._Moller-Maersk_Group&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A. P. Moller-Maersk Group (page does not exist)">Maersk</a>, the world's largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_ship_companies" title="List of ship companies">shipping company</a>, having their world headquarters in Copenhagen.
</p><p>Copenhagen has some of the highest gross wages in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> High taxes mean that wages are reduced after mandatory deduction. A <i>beneficial researcher scheme</i> with low taxation of foreign specialists has made Denmark an attractive location for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Immigration&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Immigration (page does not exist)">foreign labour</a>. It is however also among the most expensive cities in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Medicon_Valley">Medicon Valley</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Copenhagen is rich in companies and institutions with a focus on <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">research and development</a> within the <a href="/wiki/Biotechnology" title="Biotechnology">biotechnology</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Biology&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Biology (page does not exist)">life science</a> sectors.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> Two of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_pharmaceutical_companies" title="List of pharmaceutical companies">50 largest pharmaceutical and biotech companies in the world</a> are located in the greater Copenhagen area. The biotechnology and life science <a href="/w/index.php?title=Business_cluster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Business cluster (page does not exist)">cluster</a> in Copenhagen and the rest of the Øresund Region is one of the strongest in Europe. Known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Medicon_Valley&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Medicon Valley (page does not exist)">Medicon Valley</a>, it is a collaborative venture supported by both Denmark and Sweden. The aim is to strengthen the region's position and to promote cooperation between companies and <a href="/wiki/Academia" title="Academia">academia</a>. Hundreds of companies have been established in the area, the majority on the Danish side of the sound.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cleantech">Cleantech</span></h3>
<p>Launched in 2010, the Copenhagen Cleantech Cluster is the focal point of a cooperative effort between public authorities, universities, research institutions and cleantech companies. By 2012, the initiative involved 533 companies in the Greater Copenhagen area, up form 396 in 2010. The service sector, with 44% of companies, was the top sector followed by wholesale and retail trade (22%) and production (20%). The cluster employed more than 85,000 people in 2010, down from 94,000 in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> The region's most important cleantech research institutions are the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Copenhagen" title="University of Copenhagen">University of Copenhagen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Business_School" title="Copenhagen Business School">Copenhagen Business School</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ris%C3%B8_DTU_National_Laboratory_for_Sustainable_Energy" title="Risø DTU National Laboratory for Sustainable Energy">Risø DTU National Laboratory for Sustainable Energy</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Technical_University_of_Denmark" title="Technical University of Denmark">Technical University of Denmark</a> (of which Risø is now part). In 2012, companies in the Cleantech Cluster experienced growth as well as an increase in the launching of new products and services.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Cityscape">Cityscape</span></h2>
<p>The city's appearance today is shaped by the key role it has played as a regional centre for centuries. Copenhagen has a multitude of districts, each with its distinctive character and representing its own period. Other distinctive features of Copenhagen include the abundance of water, its many parks, and the <a href="/wiki/Segregated_cycle_facilities" title="Segregated cycle facilities">bicycle paths</a> that line most streets.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Amagertorv,_Copenhagen.jpg" title="File:Amagertorv, Copenhagen.jpg">File:Amagertorv, Copenhagen.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Amagertorv&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amagertorv (page does not exist)">Amagertorv</a> square dates back to the Middle Ages</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Colourful_fa%C3%A7ades_along_Nyhavn.jpg" title="File:Colourful façades along Nyhavn.jpg">File:Colourful façades along Nyhavn.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nyhavn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nyhavn (page does not exist)">Nyhavn</a>, the seventeenth century waterfront, with its colourful buildings</div></div></div>
<p>The oldest section of Copenhagen's <a href="/wiki/Inner_city" title="Inner city">inner city</a> is often referred to as <i>Middelalderbyen</i> (The <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Medieval</a> City).<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup>  However, the city's most distinctive district is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederiksstaden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederiksstaden (page does not exist)">Frederiksstaden</a>, developed during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Frederick_V_of_Denmark" title="Frederick V of Denmark">Frederick V</a>. It has the <a href="/wiki/Amalienborg" title="Amalienborg">Amalienborg Palace</a> at its centre and is dominated by the dome of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederik%27s_Church&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederik's Church (page does not exist)">Frederik's Church</a> (or the Marble Church) and several elegant 18th-century <a href="/wiki/Rococo" title="Rococo">Rococo</a> mansions.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> The inner city of Copenhagen includes <a href="/wiki/Slotsholmen" title="Slotsholmen">Slotsholmen</a>, a little island on which <a href="/wiki/Christiansborg_Palace" title="Christiansborg Palace">Christiansborg Palace</a> stands and  <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christianshavn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christianshavn (page does not exist)">Christianshavn</a> with its canals.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> Around the historical city centre lies a band of congenial residential boroughs (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Vesterbro,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vesterbro, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Vesterbro</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=N%C3%B8rrebro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nørrebro (page does not exist)">Inner Nørrebro</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indre_%C3%98sterbro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indre Østerbro (page does not exist)">Inner Østerbro</a>) dating mainly from late 19th century. They were built outside the old ramparts when the city was finally allowed to expand beyond its fortifications.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sometimes referred to as "the City of Spires", Copenhagen is known for its horizontal skyline, broken only by the spires and towers of its churches and castles. Most characteristic of all is the <a href="/wiki/Baroque" title="Baroque">Baroque</a> spire of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Church_of_Our_Saviour,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Church of Our Saviour, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Church of Our Saviour</a> with its narrowing external spiral stairway that visitors can climb to the top.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> Other important spires are those of <a href="/wiki/Christiansborg_Palace" title="Christiansborg Palace">Christiansborg Palace</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_City_Hall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen City Hall (page does not exist)">City Hall</a> and the former Church of St. Nikolaj that now houses a <a href="/wiki/Modern_art" title="Modern art">modern art</a> venue. Not quite so high are the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_architecture" title="Renaissance architecture">Renaissance</a> spires of <a href="/wiki/Rosenborg_Castle" title="Rosenborg Castle">Rosenborg Castle</a> and the "dragon spire" of <a href="/wiki/B%C3%B8rsen" title="Børsen">Christian IV's former stock exchange</a>, so named because it resembles the intertwined tails of four dragons.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Marble_Church_front.jpg" title="File:Marble Church front.jpg">File:Marble Church front.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederik%27s_Church&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederik's Church (page does not exist)">Marble Church</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederiksstaden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederiksstaden (page does not exist)">Frederiksstaden</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Recent years have seen a boom in modern architecture in Copenhagen<sup id="cite_ref-baumeister1_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-baumeister1-113">[113]</a></sup> both for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Architecture_of_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Architecture of Denmark (page does not exist)">Danish architecture</a> and for works by international architects. For a few hundred years, virtually no foreign architects had worked in Copenhagen, but since the turn of the millennium the city and its immediate surroundings have seen buildings and projects designed by top international architects. At the same time, a number of Danish architects have achieved success in Copenhagen and abroad. Buildings in Copenhagen have won <a href="/wiki/Royal_Institute_of_British_Architects" title="Royal Institute of British Architects">RIBA European Awards</a> four years in a row ("Sampension" in 2005,<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> "Kilen" in 2006,<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> "Tietgenkollegiet" in 2007 and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Danish_Playhouse&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Danish Playhouse (page does not exist)">Royal Playhouse</a> in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup>) The last three are all by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lundgaard_%26_Tranberg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lundgaard &amp; Tranberg (page does not exist)">Lundgaard &amp; Tranberg Architects</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> At the 2008 <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Architecture_Festival&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Architecture Festival (page does not exist)">World Architecture Festival</a> in Barcelona, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bjarke_Ingels&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bjarke Ingels (page does not exist)">Bjarke Ingels Group</a> won an award for the World's Best Residential Building 2008 for a house in Ørestad.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> In 2008 British design magazine <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Monocle_(2007_magazine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Monocle (2007 magazine) (page does not exist)">Monocle</a></i> named Copenhagen the <i>World's best design city 2008</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup>
</p><p>The boom in <a href="/wiki/Urban_planning" title="Urban planning">urban development</a> and <a href="/wiki/Modern_architecture" title="Modern architecture">modern architecture</a> has brought some changes to the city's skyline. A political majority has decided to keep the historical centre free of high-rise buildings, but several areas will see or have already seen massive urban development. <a href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%98restad&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ørestad (page does not exist)">Ørestad</a> now has seen most of the recent development. Located near <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Airport" title="Copenhagen Airport">Copenhagen Airport</a>, it currently boasts one of the largest malls in Scandinavia and a variety of office and residential buildings as well as the <a href="/wiki/IT_University_of_Copenhagen" title="IT University of Copenhagen">IT University</a> and a high school.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Parks">Parks</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rosenborg_-_park_setting.jpg" title="File:Rosenborg - park setting.jpg">File:Rosenborg - park setting.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Rosenborg_Castle" title="Rosenborg Castle">Rosenborg Castle</a> and park in central Copenhagen</div></div></div>
<p>Copenhagen is a green city with many parks, both large and small. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rosenborg_Castle_Gardens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rosenborg Castle Gardens (page does not exist)">King's Garden</a> (<i>Kongens Have</i>), the garden of <a href="/wiki/Rosenborg_Castle" title="Rosenborg Castle">Rosenborg Castle</a>, is the oldest and most frequented of them all.<sup id="cite_ref-www1_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-www1-121">[121]</a></sup> It was <a href="/wiki/Christian_IV_of_Denmark" title="Christian IV of Denmark">Christian IV</a> who first developed its landscaping in 1606. Every year it sees more than 2.5&#160;million visitors<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> and in the summer months it is packed with sunbathers, picnickers and ballplayers. It serves as a <a href="/wiki/Sculpture_garden" title="Sculpture garden">sculpture garden</a> with both a permanent display and temporary exhibits during the summer months.<sup id="cite_ref-www1_121-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-www1-121">[121]</a></sup> Also located in the city centre are the <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_Copenhagen_Botanical_Garden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of Copenhagen Botanical Garden (page does not exist)">Botanical Gardens</a> noted for their large complex of 19th-century greenhouses donated by <a href="/wiki/Carlsberg_Group" title="Carlsberg Group">Carlsberg</a> founder <a href="/wiki/J._C._Jacobsen" title="J. C. Jacobsen">J. C. Jacobsen</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=F%C3%A6lledparken&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fælledparken (page does not exist)">Fælledparken</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> is the largest park in Copenhagen.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> It is popular for sports fixtures and hosts several annual events including a free opera concert at the opening of the opera season, other open-air concerts, <a href="/wiki/Carnival" title="Carnival">carnival</a> and Labour Day celebrations, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Historic_Grand_Prix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Historic Grand Prix (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Historic Grand Prix</a>, a race for <a href="/wiki/Antique_car" title="Antique car">antique cars</a>. A historical <a href="/wiki/Green_belt" title="Green belt">green space</a> in the northeastern part of the city is <a href="/wiki/Kastellet,_Copenhagen" title="Kastellet, Copenhagen">Kastellet</a>, a well-preserved Renaissance <a href="/wiki/Citadel" title="Citadel">citadel</a> that now serves mainly as a park.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup>  Another popular park is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederiksberg_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederiksberg Park (page does not exist)">Frederiksberg Garden</a>, a 32-hectare <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">romantic</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Landscape_garden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Landscape garden (page does not exist)">landscape park</a>. It houses a colony of tame <a href="/wiki/Grey_Heron" title="Grey Heron">grey herons</a> and other <a href="/wiki/Waterfowl" title="Waterfowl">waterfowl</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> The park offers views of the elephants and the elephant house designed by world-famous British architect <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norman_Foster_(architect)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Norman Foster (architect) (page does not exist)">Norman Foster</a> of the adjacent <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Zoo" title="Copenhagen Zoo">Copenhagen Zoo</a>, the largest zoo in Denmark.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Langelinie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Langelinie (page does not exist)">Langelinie</a>, a park and promenade along the inner <a href="/wiki/%C3%98resund" title="Øresund">Øresund</a> coast, is home to one of Copenhagen's most-visited tourist attractions, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Little_Mermaid_(statue)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Little Mermaid (statue) (page does not exist)">Little Mermaid statue</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Copenhagen, many <a href="/wiki/Cemetery" title="Cemetery">cemeteries</a> double as parks, though only for the more quiet activities such as sunbathing, reading and meditation. <a href="/wiki/Assistens_Cemetery_(Copenhagen)" title="Assistens Cemetery (Copenhagen)">Assistens Cemetery</a>, the burial place of <a href="/wiki/Hans_Christian_Andersen" title="Hans Christian Andersen">Hans Christian Andersen</a>, is an important green space for the district of <a href="/w/index.php?title=N%C3%B8rrebro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nørrebro (page does not exist)">Inner Nørrebro</a> and a Copenhagen institution. The lesser known <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vestre_Cemetery&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vestre Cemetery (page does not exist)">Vestre Kirkegaard</a> is the largest cemetery in Denmark (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>) and offers a maze of dense groves, open lawns, winding paths, hedges, overgrown <a href="/wiki/Tomb" title="Tomb">tombs</a>, monuments, tree-lined avenues, lakes and other <a href="/wiki/List_of_garden_features" title="List of garden features">garden features</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup>
</p><p>It is official municipal policy in Copenhagen that by 2015 all citizens must be able to reach a park or beach on foot in less than 15 minutes.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> In line with this policy, several new parks, including the innovative <a href="/w/index.php?title=Superkilen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Superkilen (page does not exist)">Superkilen</a> in the Nørrebro district, have been completed or are under development in areas lacking green spaces.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Landmarks_by_district">Landmarks by district</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Indre_By">Indre By</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Christianshavns_Kanal_boats.jpg" title="File:Christianshavns Kanal boats.jpg">File:Christianshavns Kanal boats.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Christianshavn Canal</div></div></div>
<p>The historic centre of the city, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indre_By&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indre By (page does not exist)">Indre By</a> or the Inner City, features many of Copenhagen's most popular monuments and attractions. The area known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederiksstaden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederiksstaden (page does not exist)">Frederiksstaden</a>, developed by <a href="/wiki/Frederik_V_of_Denmark" title="Frederik V of Denmark" class="mw-redirect">Frederik V</a> in the second half of the 18th century in the <a href="/wiki/Rococo" title="Rococo">Rococo</a> style, has the four mansions of <a href="/wiki/Amalienborg" title="Amalienborg">Amalienborg</a>, the royal residence, and the wide-domed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederik%27s_Church&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederik's Church (page does not exist)">Marble Church</a> at its centre.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> Directly across the water from Amalienborg, the recently completed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Opera&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Opera (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Opera</a> stands on the island of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Holmen,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Holmen, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Holmen</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> To the south of Frederiksstaden, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nyhavn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nyhavn (page does not exist)">Nyhavn</a> canal is lined with colourful houses from the 17th and 18th centuries, many now with lively restaurants and bars.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> The canal runs from the harbour front to the spacious square of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kongens_Nytorv&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kongens Nytorv (page does not exist)">Kongens Nytorv</a> which was laid out by <a href="/wiki/Christian_V" title="Christian V" class="mw-redirect">Christian V</a> in 1670. Important buildings include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charlottenborg_Palace&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charlottenborg Palace (page does not exist)">Charlottenborg Palace</a>, famous for its art exhibitions, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Embassy_of_France,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Embassy of France, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Thott Palace</a> (now the French embassy), the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Danish_Theatre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Danish Theatre (page does not exist)">Royal Danish Theatre</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hotel_D%27Angleterre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hotel D'Angleterre (page does not exist)">Hotel D'Angleterre</a>, dated to 1755.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup> Other landmarks in Indre By include the parliament building of <a href="/wiki/Christiansborg" title="Christiansborg" class="mw-redirect">Christiansborg</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_City_Hall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen City Hall (page does not exist)">City Hall</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rundet%C3%A5rn" title="Rundetårn">Rundetårn</a>, originally an observatory. There are also several museums in the area including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thorvaldsen_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thorvaldsen Museum (page does not exist)">Thorvaldsen Museum</a> dedicated to the 18th-century sculptor <a href="/wiki/Bertel_Thorvaldsen" title="Bertel Thorvaldsen">Bertel Thorvaldsen</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup> Closed to traffic since 1964, <a href="/wiki/Str%C3%B8get" title="Strøget">Strøget</a>, the world's oldest and longest pedestrian street, runs the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> from Rådhuspladsen to Kongens Nytorv. With its speciality shops, cafés, restaurants, and <a href="/wiki/Buskers" title="Buskers" class="mw-redirect">buskers</a>, it is always full of life and includes the old squares of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gammel_Torv&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gammel Torv (page does not exist)">Gammel Torv</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amagertorv&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amagertorv (page does not exist)">Amagertorv</a>, each with a fountain.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rosenborg_Castle" title="Rosenborg Castle">Rosenborg Castle</a> on <a href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%98ster_Voldgade&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Øster Voldgade (page does not exist)">Øster Voldgade</a> was built by Christian IV in 1606 as a summer residence in the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_architecture" title="Renaissance architecture">Renaissance</a> style. It houses the Danish crown jewels and <a href="/wiki/Danish_Crown_Regalia" title="Danish Crown Regalia">crown regalia</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Throne_Chair_of_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Throne Chair of Denmark (page does not exist)">coronation throne</a> and tapestries illustrating Christian V's victories in the <a href="/wiki/Scanian_War" title="Scanian War">Scanian War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Christianshavn">Christianshavn</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Halmtorvet_seen_from_%C3%98ksnehallen.jpg" title="File:Halmtorvet seen from Øksnehallen.jpg">File:Halmtorvet seen from Øksnehallen.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Halmtorvet in Vesterbro</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Christianshavn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christianshavn (page does not exist)">Christianshavn</a> lies to the southeast of Indre By on the other side of the harbour. The area was developed by <a href="/wiki/Christian_IV_of_Denmark" title="Christian IV of Denmark">Christian IV</a> in the early 17th century. Impressed by the city of <a href="/wiki/Amsterdam" title="Amsterdam">Amsterdam</a>, he employed Dutch architects to create canals within its <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christianshavns_Vold&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christianshavns Vold (page does not exist)">ramparts</a> which are still well preserved today.<sup id="cite_ref-kher_10-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kher-10">[10]</a></sup> The canals themselves, branching off the central <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christianshavns_Kanal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christianshavns Kanal (page does not exist)">Christianshavn Canal</a> and  lined with house boats and pleasure craft are one of the area's attractions. Another interesting feature is <a href="/wiki/Freetown_Christiania" title="Freetown Christiania">Freetown Christiania</a>, a fairly large area which was initially occupied by squatters during student unrest in 1971. Today it still maintains a measure of autonomy. The inhabitants openly sell drugs on "Pusher Street" as well as their arts and crafts. Other buildings of interest in Christianshavn include the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Church_of_Our_Saviour,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Church of Our Saviour, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Church of Our Saviour</a> with its spiralling steeple and the magnificent Rococo <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christian%27s_Church,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christian's Church, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Christian's Church</a>. Once a warehouse, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=North_Atlantic_House&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="North Atlantic House (page does not exist)">North Atlantic House</a> now displays culture from Iceland and Greenland and houses the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Noma_(restaurant)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Noma (restaurant) (page does not exist)">Noma</a> restaurant, known for its Nordic cuisine.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Vesterbro">Vesterbro</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:N%C3%B8rrebrogade_-_beginning.jpg" title="File:Nørrebrogade - beginning.jpg">File:Nørrebrogade - beginning.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Dronning Louises Bro leading into Nørrebrogade</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vesterbro,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vesterbro, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Vesterbro</a>, to the southwest of Indre By, begins with the <a href="/wiki/Tivoli_Gardens" title="Tivoli Gardens">Tivoli Gardens</a>, the city's top tourist attraction with its fairground atmosphere, its <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pantomimeteatret&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pantomimeteatret (page does not exist)">Pantomime Theatre</a>, its <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tivolis_Koncertsal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tivolis Koncertsal (page does not exist)">Concert Hall</a> and its many rides and restaurants.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carlsberg_(district)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carlsberg (district) (page does not exist)">Carlsberg</a> quarter has some interesting vestiges of the old brewery of the same name including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elephant_Gate_and_Tower,_Carlsberg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elephant Gate and Tower, Carlsberg (page does not exist)">Elephant Gate</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ny_Carlsberg_Brewhouse&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ny Carlsberg Brewhouse (page does not exist)">Ny Carlsberg Brewhouse</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tycho_Brahe_Planetarium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tycho Brahe Planetarium (page does not exist)">Tycho Brahe Planetarium</a> is located on the edge of <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Lakes,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Lakes, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Skt. Jørgens Sø</a>, one of the Copenhagen lakes.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Halmtorvet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Halmtorvet (page does not exist)">Halmtorvet</a>, the old haymarket behind the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Central_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Central Station (page does not exist)">Central Station</a>, is an increasingly popular area with its cafés and restaurants. The former cattle market Øksnehallen has been converted into a modern exhibition centre for art and photography.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Radisson_Blu_Royal_Hotel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Radisson Blu Royal Hotel (page does not exist)">Radisson Blu Royal Hotel</a>, built by Danish architect and designer <a href="/wiki/Arne_Jacobsen" title="Arne Jacobsen">Arne Jacobsen</a> for the airline <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scandinavian_Airlines_System&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scandinavian Airlines System (page does not exist)">Scandinavian Airlines System</a> (SAS) between 1956 and 1960 was once the tallest hotel in Denmark with a height of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> and the city's only skyscraper until 1969.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> Completed in 1908, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Det_Ny_Teater&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Det Ny Teater (page does not exist)">Det Ny Teater</a> (the New Theatre) located in a passage between <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vesterbrogade&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vesterbrogade (page does not exist)">Vesterbrogade</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gammel_Kongevej&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gammel Kongevej (page does not exist)">Gammel Kongevej</a> has become a popular venue for musicals since its reopening in 1994, attracting the largest audiences in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="N.C3.B8rrebro">Nørrebro</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gefion_fountain,_Copenhagen.jpg" title="File:Gefion fountain, Copenhagen.jpg">File:Gefion fountain, Copenhagen.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Gefion Fountain</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=N%C3%B8rrebro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nørrebro (page does not exist)">Nørrebro</a> to the northwest of the city centre has recently developed from a working-class district into a colourful cosmopolitan area with antique shops, ethnic food stores and restaurants. Much of the activity is centred around <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sankt_Hans_Torv&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sankt Hans Torv (page does not exist)">Sankt Hans Torv</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup>  Copenhagen's historic cemetery, <a href="/wiki/Assistens_Cemetery_(Copenhagen)" title="Assistens Cemetery (Copenhagen)">Assistens Kirkegård</a> half way up Nørrebrogade, is the resting place of many famous figures including <a href="/wiki/S%C3%B8ren_Kierkegaard" title="Søren Kierkegaard">Søren Kierkegaard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Niels_Bohr" title="Niels Bohr">Niels Bohr</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hans_Christian_Andersen" title="Hans Christian Andersen">Hans Christian Andersen</a> but is also used by locals as a park and recreation area.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id=".C3.98sterbro">Østerbro</span></h4>
<p>Just north of the city centre, <a href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%98sterbro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Østerbro (page does not exist)">Østerbro</a> is an upper middle-class district with a number of fine mansions, some now serving as embassies.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> The district stretches from Nørrebro to the waterfront where the statue of <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Little_Mermaid_(statue)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Little Mermaid (statue) (page does not exist)">The Little Mermaid</a> can be seen from the promenade known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Langelinie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Langelinie (page does not exist)">Langelinie</a>. Inspired by <a href="/wiki/Hans_Christian_Andersen" title="Hans Christian Andersen">Hans Christian Andersen</a>'s fairy tale, it was created by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Edvard_Eriksen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Edvard Eriksen (page does not exist)">Edvard Eriksen</a> and unveiled in 1913.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup> Not far from the Little Mermaid, the old <a href="/wiki/Kastellet,_Copenhagen" title="Kastellet, Copenhagen">Citadel</a> (<i>Kastellet</i>) can be seen. Built by <a href="/wiki/Christian_IV_of_Denmark" title="Christian IV of Denmark">Christian IV</a>, it is one of northern Europe's best preserved fortifications. There is also a windmill in the area.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup> The large <a href="/wiki/Gefion_Fountain" title="Gefion Fountain">Gefion Fountain</a> (<i>Gefionspringvandet</i>) designed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anders_Bundgaard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anders Bundgaard (page does not exist)">Anders Bundgaard</a> and completed in 1908 stands close to the southeast corner of Kastellet. Its figures illustrate a Nordic legend.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Frederiksberg">Frederiksberg</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Frederiksberg_Slot_set_fra_pl%C3%A6nen.jpg" title="File:Frederiksberg Slot set fra plænen.jpg">File:Frederiksberg Slot set fra plænen.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Frederiksberg Palace</div></div></div>
<p>Strictly speaking a separate municipality, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederiksberg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederiksberg (page does not exist)">Frederiksberg</a> lies to the west of Nørrebro and Indre By and north of Vesterbro. Its landmarks include <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Zoo" title="Copenhagen Zoo">Copenhagen Zoo</a> founded in 1869 with over 250 species from all over the world and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederiksberg_Palace&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederiksberg Palace (page does not exist)">Frederiksberg Palace</a> built as a summer residence by Charles IV who was inspired by Italian architecture. Now a military academy, it overlooks the extensive landscaped gardens of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederiksberg_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederiksberg Park (page does not exist)">Frederiksberg Park</a> with its <a href="/wiki/Follies" title="Follies">follies</a>, waterfalls, lakes and decorative buildings.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup> The wide tree-lined avenue of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederiksberg_All%C3%A9&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederiksberg Allé (page does not exist)">Frederiksberg Allé</a> connecting <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vesterbrogade&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vesterbrogade (page does not exist)">Vesterbrogade</a> with the Frederiksberg Park has long been associated with theatres and entertainment. While a number of the earlier theatres are now closed, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Betty_Nansen_Teatret&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Betty Nansen Teatret (page does not exist)">Betty Nansen Theatre</a> and Aveny-T are still active.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_districts">Other districts</span></h4>
<p>Not far from <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Airport" title="Copenhagen Airport">Copenhagen Airport</a> on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kastrup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kastrup (page does not exist)">Kastrup</a> coast, <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Aquarium_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Aquarium Denmark (page does not exist)">The Blue Planet</a> completed in March 2013 now houses the national aquarium. With its 53 aquariums, it is the largest facility of its kind in Scandinavia.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grundtvig%27s_Church&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grundtvig's Church (page does not exist)">Grundtvig's Church</a>, located in the northern suburb of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bispebjerg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bispebjerg (page does not exist)">Bispebjerg</a>, was designed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=P.V._Jensen_Klint&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="P.V. Jensen Klint (page does not exist)">P.V. Jensen Klint</a> and completed in 1940. A rare example of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Expressionist_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Expressionist architecture (page does not exist)">Expressionist</a> church architecture, its striking <a href="/wiki/Westwork" title="Westwork">west façade</a> is reminiscent of a church organ.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture_and_contemporary_life">Culture and contemporary life</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Copenhagen_-_the_little_mermaid_statue_-_2013.jpg" title="File:Copenhagen - the little mermaid statue - 2013.jpg">File:Copenhagen - the little mermaid statue - 2013.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The statue of <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Little_Mermaid_(statue)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Little Mermaid (statue) (page does not exist)">the Little Mermaid</a>, an icon of the city and a popular tourist attraction.</div></div></div>
<p>Apart from being the national capital, Copenhagen also serves as the cultural hub of Denmark and wider Scandinavia. Since the late 1990s, it has undergone a transformation from a modest Scandinavian capital into a metropolitan city of international appeal in the same league as <a href="/wiki/Barcelona" title="Barcelona">Barcelona</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amsterdam" title="Amsterdam">Amsterdam</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> This is a result of huge investments in infrastructure and culture as well as the work of successful new Danish architects, designers and chefs.<sup id="cite_ref-baumeister1_113-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-baumeister1-113">[113]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-iht2007_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iht2007-158">[158]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Fashion_Week&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Fashion Week (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Fashion Week</a>, the largest fashion event in Northern Europe, takes place every year in February and August.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Museums">Museums</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Copenhagen has a wide array of museums of international standing. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Museum_of_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Museum of Denmark (page does not exist)">National Museum</a>, <i>Nationalmuseet</i>, is Denmark's largest museum of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Archaeology&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Archaeology (page does not exist)">archaeology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cultural_history" title="Cultural history">cultural history</a>, comprising the histories of Danish and foreign cultures alike.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup> Denmark's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Statens_Museum_for_Kunst&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Statens Museum for Kunst (page does not exist)">National Gallery</a> (<i>Statens Museum for Kunst</i>) is the national art museum with collections dating from the 12th century to the present. In addition to Danish painters, artists represented in the collections include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peter_Paul_Rubens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peter Paul Rubens (page does not exist)">Rubens</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rembrandt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rembrandt (page does not exist)">Rembrandt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pablo_Picasso" title="Pablo Picasso">Picasso</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georges_Braque" title="Georges Braque">Braque</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fernand_L%C3%A9ger" title="Fernand Léger">Léger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Henri_Matisse" title="Henri Matisse">Matisse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emil_Nolde" title="Emil Nolde">Emil Nolde</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Olafur_Eliasson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Olafur Eliasson (page does not exist)">Olafur Eliasson</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elmgreen_and_Dragset&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elmgreen and Dragset (page does not exist)">Elmgreen and Dragset</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Superflex&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Superflex (page does not exist)">Superflex</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jens_Haaning&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jens Haaning (page does not exist)">Jens Haaning</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup>
</p><p>Another important Copenhagen art museum is the <a href="/wiki/Ny_Carlsberg_Glyptotek" title="Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek">Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek</a> founded by second generation <a href="/wiki/Carlsberg_Group" title="Carlsberg Group">Carlsberg</a> philanthropist <a href="/wiki/Carl_Jacobsen" title="Carl Jacobsen">Carl Jacobsen</a> and built around his personal collections. Its main focus is classical <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">Egyptian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Greek</a> sculptures and antiquities and a collection of <a href="/wiki/Auguste_Rodin" title="Auguste Rodin">Rodin</a> sculptures, the largest outside France. Besides its sculpture collections, the museum also holds a comprehensive collection of paintings of <a href="/wiki/Impressionism" title="Impressionism">Impressionist</a> and <a href="/wiki/Post-Impressionism" title="Post-Impressionism">Post-Impressionist</a> painters such as <a href="/wiki/Claude_Monet" title="Claude Monet">Monet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pierre-Auguste_Renoir" title="Pierre-Auguste Renoir">Renoir</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paul_C%C3%A9zanne" title="Paul Cézanne">Cézanne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vincent_van_Gogh" title="Vincent van Gogh">van Gogh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Henri_de_Toulouse-Lautrec" title="Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec">Toulouse-Lautrec</a> as well as works by the Danish <a href="/w/index.php?title=Golden_Age&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Golden Age (page does not exist)">Golden Age</a> painters.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Louisiana_Museum_of_Modern_Art" title="Louisiana Museum of Modern Art">Louisiana</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Museum_of_Modern_Art" title="Museum of Modern Art">museum of modern art</a> situated on the coast just north of Copenhagen. It is located in the middle of a sculpture garden on a cliff overlooking <a href="/wiki/%C3%98resund" title="Øresund">Øresund</a>. Its collection of over 3,000 items includes works by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Picasso&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Picasso (page does not exist)">Picasso</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alberto_Giacometti" title="Alberto Giacometti">Giacometti</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dubuffet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dubuffet (page does not exist)">Dubuffet</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Danish_Museum_of_Art_%26_Design" title="Danish Museum of Art &amp; Design">Danish Design Museum</a> is housed in the 18th-century former <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederiks_Hospital&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederiks Hospital (page does not exist)">Frederiks Hospital</a> and displays <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_design&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish design (page does not exist)">Danish design</a> as well as international design and crafts.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other museums include: the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thorvaldsens_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thorvaldsens Museum (page does not exist)">Thorvaldsens Museum</a>, dedicated to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Work_of_art&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Work of art (page does not exist)">oeuvre</a> of romantic Danish sculptor <a href="/wiki/Bertel_Thorvaldsen" title="Bertel Thorvaldsen">Bertel Thorvaldsen</a> who lived and worked in Rome;<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup> the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cisternerne&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cisternerne (page does not exist)">Cisternerne</a> museum  dedicated to modern <a href="/wiki/Studio_glass" title="Studio glass">glass art</a>, located in former <a href="/wiki/Cistern" title="Cistern">cisterns</a> that come complete with <a href="/wiki/Stalactite" title="Stalactite">stalactites</a> formed by the changing water levels;<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ordrupgaard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ordrupgaard (page does not exist)">Ordrupgaard Museum</a>, located just north of Copenhagen, which features 19th-century French and Danish art and is noted for its works by <a href="/wiki/Paul_Gauguin" title="Paul Gauguin">Paul Gauguin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Entertainment_and_performing_arts">Entertainment and performing arts</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Copenhagen_Opera_House_at_Night.jpg" title="File:Copenhagen Opera House at Night.jpg">File:Copenhagen Opera House at Night.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Opera_House&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Opera House (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Opera House</a> at night.</div></div></div>
<p>The new <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Concert_Hall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Concert Hall (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Concert Hall</a> opened in January 2009. Designed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jean_Nouvel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jean Nouvel (page does not exist)">Jean Nouvel</a>, it has four halls with the main <a href="/wiki/Auditorium" title="Auditorium">auditorium</a> seating 1,800 people. It serves as the home of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_National_Symphony_Orchestra&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish National Symphony Orchestra (page does not exist)">Danish National Symphony Orchestra</a> and along with the <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_Concert_Hall" title="Walt Disney Concert Hall">Walt Disney Concert Hall</a> in Los Angeles is the most expensive concert hall ever built.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup> Another important venue for classical music is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tivoli_Concert_Hall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tivoli Concert Hall (page does not exist)">Tivoli Concert Hall</a> located in the <a href="/wiki/Tivoli_Gardens" title="Tivoli Gardens">Tivoli Gardens</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup> Designed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Henning_Larsen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Henning Larsen (page does not exist)">Henning Larsen</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Opera_House&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Opera House (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Opera House</a> (<i>Operaen</i>) opened in 2005. It is among the most modern opera houses in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Danish_Theatre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Danish Theatre (page does not exist)">Royal Danish Theatre</a> also stages opera in addition to its drama productions. It is also home to the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Danish_Ballet" title="Royal Danish Ballet">Royal Danish Ballet</a>. Founded in 1748 along with the theatre, it is one of the oldest ballet troupes in Europe noted for its <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bournonville_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bournonville School (page does not exist)">Bournonville style</a> of ballet.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup> 
</p>
