<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Royal_Danish_Theatre,_Copenhagen.jpg" title="File:Royal Danish Theatre, Copenhagen.jpg">File:Royal Danish Theatre, Copenhagen.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Danish_Theatre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Danish Theatre (page does not exist)">Royal Danish Theatre</a></div></div></div>
<p>Copenhagen has a significant <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a> scene that has existed for many years. It developed when a number of American <a href="/wiki/List_of_jazz_musicians" title="List of jazz musicians">jazz musicians</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Ben_Webster" title="Ben Webster">Ben Webster</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thad_Jones" title="Thad Jones">Thad Jones</a>, <a href="/wiki/Richard_B._Boone" title="Richard B. Boone">Richard Boone</a>, Ernie Wilkins, <a href="/wiki/Kenny_Drew" title="Kenny Drew">Kenny Drew</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ed_Thigpen" title="Ed Thigpen">Ed Thigpen</a>, Bob Rockwell, <a href="/wiki/Dexter_Gordon" title="Dexter Gordon">Dexter Gordon</a>, and others such as <a href="/wiki/Guitarist" title="Guitarist">rock guitarist</a> <a href="/wiki/Link_Wray" title="Link Wray">Link Wray</a> came to live in Copenhagen during the 1960s. Every year in early July, Copenhagen's streets, squares, parks as well as cafés and concert halls fill up with big and small jazz concerts during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Jazz_Festival&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Jazz Festival (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Jazz Festival</a>. One of Europe's top jazz festivals, the annual event features around 900 concerts at 100 venues with over 200,000 guests from Denmark and around the world.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>The largest venue for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Popular_music&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Popular music (page does not exist)">popular music</a> in Copenhagen is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vega,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vega, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Vega</a> in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vesterbro,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vesterbro, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Vesterbro</a> district. It was chosen as "best concert venue in Europe" by international music magazine <i>Live</i>. The venue has three concert halls: the great hall, Store Vega, accommodates audiences of 1,550, the middle hall, Lille Vega, has space for 500 and Ideal Bar Live has a capacity of 250.<sup id="cite_ref-vega_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vega-173">[173]</a></sup> Every September since 2006, the Festival of Endless Gratitude (FOEG) has taken place in Copenhagen. This festival focuses on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indie_art&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indie art (page does not exist)">indie</a> <a href="/wiki/Counterculture" title="Counterculture">counterculture</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Experimental_rock&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Experimental rock (page does not exist)">experimental pop music</a> and <a href="/wiki/Left_field" title="Left field" class="mw-redirect">left field</a> music combined with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Visual_arts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Visual arts (page does not exist)">visual arts</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Exhibition&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Exhibition (page does not exist)">exhibitions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup>
</p><p>For free entertainment one can stroll along <a href="/wiki/Str%C3%B8get" title="Strøget">Strøget</a>, especially between <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nytorv&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nytorv (page does not exist)">Nytorv</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=H%C3%B8jbro_Plads&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Højbro Plads (page does not exist)">Højbro Plads</a>, which in the late afternoon and evening is a bit like an impromptu three-ring <a href="/wiki/Circus" title="Circus">circus</a> with musicians, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Magic_(illusion)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Magic (illusion) (page does not exist)">magicians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Juggling" title="Juggling">jugglers</a> and other <a href="/w/index.php?title=Busking&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Busking (page does not exist)">street performers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Koebenhavns_Hovedbibliotek_midterparti.JPG" title="File:Koebenhavns Hovedbibliotek midterparti.JPG">File:Koebenhavns Hovedbibliotek midterparti.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Copenhagen's main public library</div></div></div>
<p>Most of Denmarks's major publishing houses are based in Copenhagen.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> These include the book publishers <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gyldendal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gyldendal (page does not exist)">Gyldendal</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Akademisk_Forlag&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Akademisk Forlag (page does not exist)">Akademisk Forlag</a> and newspaper publishers <a href="/wiki/Berlingske" title="Berlingske">Berlingske</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=JP/Politikens_Hus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="JP/Politikens Hus (page does not exist)">Politiken</a> (the latter also publishing books).<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup> Many of the most important contributors to Danish literature such as Hans Christian Andersen (1805–1875) with his fairy tales, the philosopher Søren Kierkegaard (1813–1855) and playwright <a href="/wiki/Ludvig_Holberg" title="Ludvig Holberg">Ludvig Holberg</a> (1684–1754) spent much of their lives in Copenhagen. Novels set in Copenhagen include <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Baby_(Thorup_novel)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baby (Thorup novel) (page does not exist)">Baby</a></i> (1973) by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kirsten_Thorup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kirsten Thorup (page does not exist)">Kirsten Thorup</a>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Copenhagen_Connection_(novel)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Copenhagen Connection (novel) (page does not exist)">The Copenhagen Connection</a></i> (1982) by <a href="/wiki/Barbara_Mertz" title="Barbara Mertz">Barbara Mertz</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Number_the_Stars" title="Number the Stars">Number the Stars</a></i> (1989) by <a href="/wiki/Lois_Lowry" title="Lois Lowry">Lois Lowry</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Miss_Smilla%27s_Feeling_for_Snow" title="Miss Smilla's Feeling for Snow">Miss Smilla's Feeling for Snow</a></i> (1992) and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Borderliners&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Borderliners (page does not exist)">Borderliners</a></i> (1993) by <a href="/wiki/Peter_H%C3%B8eg" title="Peter Høeg">Peter Høeg</a>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Music_and_Silence&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Music and Silence (page does not exist)">Music and Silence</a></i> (1999) by <a href="/wiki/Rose_Tremain" title="Rose Tremain">Rose Tremain</a>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Danish_Girl&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Danish Girl (page does not exist)">The Danish Girl</a></i> (2000) by <a href="/w/index.php?title=David_Ebershoff&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="David Ebershoff (page does not exist)">David Ebershoff</a>, and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sharpe%27s_Prey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sharpe's Prey (page does not exist)">Sharpe's Prey</a></i> (2001) by <a href="/wiki/Bernard_Cornwell" title="Bernard Cornwell">Bernard Cornwell</a>. <a href="/wiki/Michael_Frayn" title="Michael Frayn">Michael Frayn</a>'s 1998 play <i><a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_(play)" title="Copenhagen (play)">Copenhagen</a></i> about the meeting between the <a href="/wiki/Physicist" title="Physicist">physicists</a> <a href="/wiki/Niels_Bohr" title="Niels Bohr">Niels Bohr</a> and <a href="/wiki/Werner_Heisenberg" title="Werner Heisenberg">Werner Heisenberg</a> in 1941 is also set in the city. From August 15–18, 1973, an oral literature conference took place in Copenhagen as part of the 9th International Congress of Anthropological and Ethnological Sciences.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Library,_Denmark" title="Royal Library, Denmark">Royal Library</a>, Denmark's national library, which also serves as the library of the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Copenhagen" title="University of Copenhagen">University of Copenhagen</a> is the largest library in the Nordic countries with an almost complete collection of all printed Danish books since 1482. Founded in 1648, the library is located at four sites in the city, the main one being on the Slotsholmen waterfront.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup> Copenhagen's public library network has over 20 outlets, the largest being the Central Library (<i>Københavns Hovedbibliotek</i>) on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Krystalgade&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Krystalgade (page does not exist)">Krystalgade</a> in the inner city.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Art">Art</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Jailhouse_at_Nytorv,_Copenhagen_-_Martinus_R%C3%B8rbye.jpg" title="File:Jailhouse at Nytorv, Copenhagen - Martinus Rørbye.jpg">File:Jailhouse at Nytorv, Copenhagen - Martinus Rørbye.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Martinus Rørbye: <i>Jailhouse at Nytorv</i> (1831)</div></div></div>
<p>Copenhagen has a wide selection of art museums and galleries displaying both historic works and more modern contributions. They include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Statens_Museum_for_Kunst&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Statens Museum for Kunst (page does not exist)">Statens Museum for Kunst</a>, the Danish national gallery, in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%98stre_Anl%C3%A6g&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Østre Anlæg (page does not exist)">Østre Anlæg</a> park and the adjacent <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hirschsprung_Collection&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hirschsprung Collection (page does not exist)">Hirschsprung Collection</a> specialising in the 19th and early 20th century. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kunsthal_Charlottenborg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kunsthal Charlottenborg (page does not exist)">Kunsthal Charlottenborg</a> in the city centre exhibits national and international contemporary art. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Den_Frie_Udstilling&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Den Frie Udstilling (page does not exist)">Den Frie Udstilling</a> near the <a href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%98sterport_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Østerport Station (page does not exist)">Østerport Station</a> exhibits paintings created and selected by contemporary artists themselves rather than by the official authorities. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arken_Museum_of_Modern_Art&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arken Museum of Modern Art (page does not exist)">Arken Museum of Modern Art</a> is located in southwestern <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ish%C3%B8j&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ishøj (page does not exist)">Ishøj</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup> Among artists who have painted scenes of Copenhagen are <a href="/wiki/Martinus_R%C3%B8rbye" title="Martinus Rørbye">Martinus Rørbye</a> (1803–1848),<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Christen_K%C3%B8bke" title="Christen Købke">Christen Købke</a> (1810–1848)<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> and the prolific <a href="/w/index.php?title=Paul_Gustav_Fischer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Paul Gustav Fischer (page does not exist)">Paul Gustav Fischer</a> (1860–1934).<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup>
</p><p>A number of notable sculptures can be see in the city. In addition to the Little Mermaid on the waterfront, there are two historic equestrian statues in the city centre: <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Saly" title="Jacques Saly">Jacques Saly</a>'s <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederik_V_on_Horseback&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederik V on Horseback (page does not exist)">Frederik V on Horseback</a></i> (1771) in Amalienborg Square<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup> and the statue of <a href="/wiki/Christian_V_of_Denmark" title="Christian V of Denmark">Christian V</a> on Kongens Nytorv created by Abraham-César Lamoureux in 1688 who was inspired by the statue of <a href="/wiki/Louis_XIII_of_France" title="Louis XIII of France">Louis XIII</a> in Paris.<sup id="cite_ref-N.C3.B8rreg.C3.A5rd-Nielsen2009_185-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-N.C3.B8rreg.C3.A5rd-Nielsen2009-185">[185]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_public_art_in_Rosenborg_Castle_Gardens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of public art in Rosenborg Castle Gardens (page does not exist)">Rosenborg Castle Gardens</a> contains several sculptures and monuments including <a href="/w/index.php?title=August_Saabye&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="August Saabye (page does not exist)">August Saabye</a>'s Hans Christian Andersen, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aksel_Hansen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aksel Hansen (page does not exist)">Aksel Hansen</a>'s Echo, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vilhelm_Bissen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vilhelm Bissen (page does not exist)">Vilhelm Bissen</a>'s <a href="/w/index.php?title=Caroline_Amalie_of_Augustenburg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Caroline Amalie of Augustenburg (page does not exist)">Dowager Queen Caroline Amalie</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<div class="dablink">For a broader look at this topic, see <a href="/wiki/Danish_cuisine" title="Danish cuisine">Danish cuisine</a>.</div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Noma_entrance.jpg" title="File:Noma entrance.jpg">File:Noma entrance.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Noma_(restaurant)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Noma (restaurant) (page does not exist)">Noma</a> is an example of Copenhagen's renowned experimental restaurants, and has gained two Michelin stars.</div></div></div>
<p>As of 2013, Copenhagen has 13 <a href="/wiki/Michelin_Guide" title="Michelin Guide">Michelin star</a> restaurants, the most of any Scandinavian city.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup> The city is increasingly recognized internationally as a gourmet destination.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup> These include Den Røde Cottage, Formel B Restaurant, Grønbech &amp; Churchill, Søllerød Kro, Kadeau, Kiin Kiin (Denmark's first Michelin-starred Asian gourmet restaurant), the French restaurant Kong Hans Kælder, Relæ, Restaurant AOC, and, each with two Michelin stars,  <a href="/w/index.php?title=Geranium_(restaurant)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Geranium (restaurant) (page does not exist)">Geranium</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Noma_(restaurant)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Noma (restaurant) (page does not exist)">Noma</a> (short for Danish: <i>no</i>rdisk <i>ma</i>d, English: Nordic food). Noma, was ranked as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Restaurant_(magazine)_Top_50&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Restaurant (magazine) Top 50 (page does not exist)">Best Restaurant in the World</a> by <i><a href="/wiki/Restaurant_(magazine)" title="Restaurant (magazine)">Restaurant</a></i> in 2010, 2011 and 2012, sparking interest in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Nordic_Cuisine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Nordic Cuisine (page does not exist)">New Nordic Cuisine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup>
</p><p>Apart from the selection of upmarket restaurants, Copenhagen offers a great variety of Danish, ethnic and experimental restaurants. It is possible to find modest eateries serving <a href="/wiki/Open_sandwich" title="Open sandwich">open sandwiches</a>, known as <a href="/wiki/Sm%C3%B8rrebr%C3%B8d" title="Smørrebrød">smørrebrød</a> – a traditional, Danish lunch dish; however, most restaurants serve international dishes.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Danish_pastry" title="Danish pastry">Danish pastry</a> can be sampled from any of numerous bakeries found in all parts of the city. The Copenhagen Baker's Association dates back to the 1290s and Denmark's oldest confectioner's shop still operating, <i>Conditori La Glace</i>, was founded in 1870 in Skoubogade by Nicolaus Henningsen, a trained master baker from <a href="/wiki/Flensburg" title="Flensburg">Flensburg</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup>
</p><p>Copenhagen has long been associated with beer. <a href="/wiki/Carlsberg_Group" title="Carlsberg Group">Carlsberg</a> beer has been brewed at the brewery's premises on the border between the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vesterbro,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vesterbro, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Vesterbro</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Valby&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Valby (page does not exist)">Valby</a> districts since 1847 and has long been almost synonymous with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beer_in_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beer in Denmark (page does not exist)">Danish beer</a> production. However, recent years have seen an explosive growth in the number of <a href="/wiki/Microbrewery" title="Microbrewery">microbreweries</a> so that Denmark today has more than 100 breweries, many of which are located in Copenhagen. Some like <i>Nørrebro Bryghus</i> also act as <a href="/wiki/Brewpubs" title="Brewpubs" class="mw-redirect">brewpubs</a> where it is also possible to eat on the premises.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[192]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nightlife_and_festivals">Nightlife and festivals</span></h3>
<p>Copenhagen has one of the highest number of restaurants and bars per capita in the world. The nightclubs stay open until 5 or 6 in the morning, some even longer. Denmark has a very liberal alcohol culture and a strong tradition for beer breweries, although binge drinking is frowned upon and the Danish Police take <a href="/wiki/Driving_under_the_influence" title="Driving under the influence">driving under the influence</a> very seriously.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup> Inner city areas such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Istedgade&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Istedgade (page does not exist)">Istedgade</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Enghave_Plads&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Enghave Plads (page does not exist)">Enghave Plads</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vesterbro_(Copenhagen)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vesterbro (Copenhagen) (page does not exist)">Vesterbro</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sankt_Hans_Torv&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sankt Hans Torv (page does not exist)">Sankt Hans Torv</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=N%C3%B8rrebro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nørrebro (page does not exist)">Nørrebro</a> and certain places in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederiksberg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederiksberg (page does not exist)">Frederiksberg</a> are vibrant and full of life even during the late hours. Notable nightclubs include Bakken Kbh, HIVE, Jolene, The Jane on Gråbrødre Square, Karriere Bar, KB3, Rust, Vega Nighclub, Culture Box and Gefährlich, which also serves as a bar, café, restaurant, and art gallery.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup>
</p><p>Copenhagen has several recurring community festivals, mainly in the summer. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Carnival&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Carnival (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Carnival</a> has taken place every year since 1982 during the <a href="/wiki/Whitsun" title="Whitsun">Whitsun</a> Holiday in <a href="/w/index.php?title=F%C3%A6lledparken&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fælledparken (page does not exist)">Fælledparken</a> and around the city with the participation of 120 bands, 2,000 dancers and 100,000 spectators.<sup id="cite_ref-Timeline_196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Timeline-196">[196]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Pride&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Pride (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Pride</a> is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gay_pride&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gay pride (page does not exist)">gay pride festival</a> taking place every year in August. Among the events is "Tivoli goes pink" which ends with a parade. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Distortion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Distortion (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Distortion</a> is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Youth_subculture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Youth subculture (page does not exist)">youth culture</a> festival capturing the zeitgeist of the city. Every year (five days up to the first weekend of June) it attracts up to 100,000 people in the streets, shops, galleries, clubs, bars, in boats and buses, with a cultural focus on street culture, art and upfront <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dance_music&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dance music (page does not exist)">dance music</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Amusement_parks">Amusement parks</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pantomime_Theatre.jpg" title="File:Pantomime Theatre.jpg">File:Pantomime Theatre.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pantomimeteatret&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pantomimeteatret (page does not exist)">Pantomime Theatre</a>, opened in 1874, is the oldest building in the <a href="/wiki/Tivoli_Gardens" title="Tivoli Gardens">Tivoli Gardens</a> amusement park.</div></div></div>
<p>Copenhagen has the two oldest <a href="/wiki/Amusement_parks" title="Amusement parks" class="mw-redirect">amusement parks</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-www3_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-www3-198">[198]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Dyrehavsbakken" title="Dyrehavsbakken">Dyrehavsbakken</a>, a fair-ground and pleasure-park established in 1583, is located in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Klampenborg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Klampenborg (page does not exist)">Klampenborg</a> just north of Copenhagen in a forested area known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=J%C3%A6gersborg_Dyrehave&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jægersborg Dyrehave (page does not exist)">Dyrehaven</a>. Created as an amusement park complete with rides, games and restaurants by <a href="/wiki/Christian_IV_of_Denmark" title="Christian IV of Denmark">Christian IV</a>, it is the oldest surviving amusement park in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-www3_198-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-www3-198">[198]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pierrot#Denmark" title="Pierrot">Pierrot</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-da&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-da (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-da</a>), a nitwit dressed in white with a scarlet grin wearing a boat-like hat while entertaining children, remains one of the park's key attractions. In Danish, Dyrehavsbakken is often abbreviated as <i>Bakken</i>. There is no entrance fee to pay and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Klampenborg_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Klampenborg Station (page does not exist)">Klampenborg Station</a> on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=C_(S-train)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="C (S-train) (page does not exist)">C-line</a>, is situated nearby.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Tivoli_Gardens" title="Tivoli Gardens">Tivoli Gardens</a> is an amusement park and pleasure garden located in central Copenhagen between the <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_City_Hall_Square,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The City Hall Square, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">City Hall Square</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Central_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Central Station (page does not exist)">Central Station</a>. It opened in 1843, making it the second oldest amusement park in the world. Among its rides are the oldest still operating rollercoaster <i>Rutschebanen</i> from 1915 and the oldest <a href="/wiki/Ferris_wheel" title="Ferris wheel">ferris wheel</a> still in use, opened in 1943.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup>  Tivoli Gardens also serves as a venue for various performing arts and as an active part of the cultural scene in Copenhagen.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:University_Main_Building.jpg" title="File:University Main Building.jpg">File:University Main Building.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/University_of_Copenhagen" title="University of Copenhagen">University of Copenhagen</a> main building</div></div></div>
<p>Copenhagen has over 94,000 students enrolled in its largest universities and institutions: <a href="/wiki/University_of_Copenhagen" title="University of Copenhagen">University of Copenhagen</a> (38,867 students),<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup>  <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Business_School" title="Copenhagen Business School">Copenhagen Business School</a> (19,999 students),<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Metropolitan_University_College&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Metropolitan University College (page does not exist)">Metropolitan University College</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_College_Capital&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University College Capital (page does not exist)">University College Capital</a> (10,000 students each),<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Technical_University_of_Denmark" title="Technical University of Denmark">Technical University of Denmark</a> (7,000 students),<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup> KEA (c. 4,500 students),<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/IT_University_of_Copenhagen" title="IT University of Copenhagen">IT University of Copenhagen</a> (2,000 students.) and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aalborg_University_%E2%80%93_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aalborg University – Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Aalborg University – Copenhagen</a> (2,300 students).<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup>
</p><p>Copenhagen's higher-education system relies on <a href="/wiki/Public_university" title="Public university">public universities</a>. Most prominent among these is the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Copenhagen" title="University of Copenhagen">University of Copenhagen</a>. Founded in 1479, it is the oldest university in Denmark. A world-renowned research and teaching institution with campuses around the city, it forms part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_Alliance_of_Research_Universities&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International Alliance of Research Universities (page does not exist)">International Alliance of Research Universities</a> (IARU), which encourages international collaboration between top universities including <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University" title="Oxford University" class="mw-redirect">Oxford</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cambridge_University" title="Cambridge University" class="mw-redirect">Cambridge</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yale_University" title="Yale University">Yale</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_California,_Berkeley" title="University of California, Berkeley">Berkeley</a> and <a href="/wiki/Australian_National_University" title="Australian National University">The Australian National University</a>. The University attracts some 1,500 international and exchange students every year.
It has repeatedly been ranked as one of the best universities in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Copenhagen_business_school.jpg" title="File:Copenhagen business school.jpg">File:Copenhagen business school.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Copenhagen Business School</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Technical_University_of_Denmark" title="Technical University of Denmark">Technical University of Denmark</a> (DTU), <i>Danmarks Tekniske Universitet</i>, is located in <a href="/wiki/Kongens_Lyngby" title="Kongens Lyngby">Lyngby</a> in the northern outskirts of Copenhagen. In 2013, it was ranked as one of the leading technical universities in Northern Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup>  The <a href="/wiki/IT_University_of_Copenhagen" title="IT University of Copenhagen">IT University of Copenhagen</a> is Denmark's youngest university, a mono-faculty institution focusing on technical, societal and business aspects of information technology.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Royal_Danish_Academy_of_Fine_Arts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts (page does not exist)">The Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts</a> (<i>Det Kongelige Danske Kunstakademi</i>) has provided a practice-oriented complement to the scholarly investigation of the arts carried out at Danish universities for more than 250 years. It includes the historical School of Visual Arts, and has in later years come to include a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kunstakademiets_Arkitektskole&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kunstakademiets Arkitektskole (page does not exist)">School of Architecture</a>, a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danmarks_Designskole&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danmarks Designskole (page does not exist)">School of Design</a> and a School of Conservation.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[212]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Business_School" title="Copenhagen Business School">Copenhagen Business School</a> (CBS) is an <a href="/wiki/European_Quality_Improvement_System" title="European Quality Improvement System">EQUIS</a>-accredited business&#160;school located in <a href="/wiki/Frederiksberg_Municipality" title="Frederiksberg Municipality">Frederiksberg</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup>
There are also branches of both <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_College_Capital&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University College Capital (page does not exist)">University College Capital</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Metropolitan_University_College&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Metropolitan University College (page does not exist)">Metropolitan University College</a> inside and outside Copenhagen.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[215]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">Sport</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kparken.JPG" title="File:Kparken.JPG">File:Kparken.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Parken_Stadium" title="Parken Stadium">Parken Stadium</a></div></div></div>
<p>Copenhagen is home to a great number of fitness and health clubs owned by a number of chains including "Fitness World" and "Fitness dk".<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup> They are popular with all age groups. In the summer, bikers, runners and strollers can be seen on the paths around the city's <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Lakes,_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Lakes, Copenhagen (page does not exist)">five rectangular lakes</a> which total a distance of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. The municipal authorities encourage people to use bicycles as their primary form of transportation when moving around the city.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city has a variety of sporting teams. The major <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a> teams are the historically successful <a href="/wiki/F.C._Copenhagen" title="F.C. Copenhagen">FC København</a><sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Br%C3%B8ndby_IF" title="Brøndby IF">Brøndby</a>. FC København plays at <a href="/wiki/Parken_Stadium" title="Parken Stadium">Parken</a> in Østerbro. Formed in 1992, it is a merger of two older Copenhagen clubs, B 1903 (from the inner suburb Gentofte) and KB (from Frederiksberg).<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup> Brøndby plays at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Br%C3%B8ndby_Stadion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brøndby Stadion (page does not exist)">Brøndby Stadion</a> in the inner suburb of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Br%C3%B8ndbyvester&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brøndbyvester (page does not exist)">Brøndbyvester</a>. BK Frem is based in the southern part of Copenhagen (Sydhavnen, Valby). Other teams are <a href="/w/index.php?title=FC_Nordsj%C3%A6lland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="FC Nordsjælland (page does not exist)">FC Nordsjælland</a> (from suburban <a href="/w/index.php?title=Farum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Farum (page does not exist)">Farum</a>), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fremad_Amager&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fremad Amager (page does not exist)">Fremad Amager</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Boldklubben_1893&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Boldklubben 1893 (page does not exist)">B93</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Akademisk_Boldklub&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Akademisk Boldklub (page does not exist)">AB</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Boldklubben_Frem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Boldklubben Frem (page does not exist)">Frem</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lyngby_Boldklub" title="Lyngby Boldklub">Lyngby</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hvidovre_IF" title="Hvidovre IF">Hvidovre IF</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nysport_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nysport-220">[220]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Copenhagen_Marathon_2008.jpg" title="File:Copenhagen Marathon 2008.jpg">File:Copenhagen Marathon 2008.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Marathon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Marathon (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Marathon</a> 2008</div></div></div>
<p>Copenhagen has several <a href="/w/index.php?title=Team_handball&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Team handball (page does not exist)">handball teams</a>—a sport which is particularly popular in Denmark. Of clubs playing in the "highest" leagues, there are Ajax, Ydun, and HIK (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Hellerup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hellerup (page does not exist)">Hellerup</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-nysport_220-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nysport-220">[220]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=K%C3%B8benhavn_H%C3%A5ndbold&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="København Håndbold (page does not exist)">København Håndbold</a> women's club has recently been established.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup> Copenhagen also has <a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey" title="Ice hockey">ice hockey</a> teams, of which three play in the top league, <a href="/w/index.php?title=R%C3%B8dovre_Mighty_Bulls&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rødovre Mighty Bulls (page does not exist)">Rødovre Mighty Bulls</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Herlev_Hornets&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Herlev Hornets (page does not exist)">Herlev Eagles</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hvidovre_Ligahockey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hvidovre Ligahockey (page does not exist)">Hvidovre Ligahockey</a> all inner suburban clubs. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kj%C3%B8benhavns_Sk%C3%B8jtel%C3%B8berforening&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kjøbenhavns Skøjteløberforening (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Ice Skating Club</a> founded in 1869 is the oldest ice hockey team in Denmark but is no longer in the top league.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">Rugby union</a> is also played in the Danish capital with teams such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=CSR-Nanok&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="CSR-Nanok (page does not exist)">CSR-Nanok</a>, Copenhagen Business School Sport Rugby, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederiksberg_RK&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederiksberg RK (page does not exist)">Frederiksberg RK</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=RK_Speed&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="RK Speed (page does not exist)">Rugbyklubben Speed</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rugby_League&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rugby League (page does not exist)">Rugby League</a> is now played in Copenhagen, with the national team playing out of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gentofte_Stadion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gentofte Stadion (page does not exist)">Gentofte Stadion</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_Australian_Football_League&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish Australian Football League (page does not exist)">Danish Australian Football League</a>, based in Copenhagen is the largest <a href="/wiki/Australian_rules_football" title="Australian rules football">Australian rules football</a> competition outside of the <a href="/wiki/Anglosphere" title="Anglosphere">English speaking world</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nysport_220-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nysport-220">[220]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[223]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Marathon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Marathon (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Marathon</a>, Copenhagen's annual <a href="/wiki/Marathon" title="Marathon">marathon</a> event, was established in 1980.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[224]</a></sup>
<a href="/wiki/Slotsholmen#Round_Christiansborg_Open_Water_Swim" title="Slotsholmen">Round Christiansborg Open Water Swim Race</a> is a 2&#160;km (1.2&#160;mi) <a href="/w/index.php?title=Open_water_swimming&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Open water swimming (page does not exist)">open water swimming</a> competition taking place each year in late August.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[225]</a></sup> This amateur event is combined with a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> Danish championship.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[226]</a></sup> In 2009 the event included a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> FINA World Cup competition in the morning. Copenhagen hosted the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_UCI_Road_World_Championships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 UCI Road World Championships (page does not exist)">2011 UCI Road World Championships</a> in September 2011, taking advantage of its bicycle-friendly infrastructure. It was the first time that Denmark had hosted the event since 1956, when it was also held in Copenhagen.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[227]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:KastrupAirport_Panorama.jpg" title="File:KastrupAirport Panorama.jpg">File:KastrupAirport Panorama.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Airport" title="Copenhagen Airport">Copenhagen Airport</a></div></div></div>
<p>The greater Copenhagen area has a very well established transportation infrastructure making it a hub in Northern Europe. <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Airport" title="Copenhagen Airport">Copenhagen Airport</a>, opened in 1925, is Scandinavia's largest airport, located in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kastrup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kastrup (page does not exist)">Kastrup</a> on the island of Amager. It is connected to the city centre by metro and main line railway services.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[228]</a></sup> October 2013 was a record month with 2.2 million passengers, and November 2013 figures reveal that the number of passengers is increasing by some 3% annually, about 50% more than the European average.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[229]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:4th_generation_S-train_at_Copenhagen_Central_Station.jpg" title="File:4th generation S-train at Copenhagen Central Station.jpg">File:4th generation S-train at Copenhagen Central Station.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">4th generation <a href="/wiki/S-train" title="S-train">S-train</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Central_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Central Station (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Central Station</a></div></div></div>
<p>Copenhagen is served by a daily ferry connection to <a href="/wiki/Oslo" title="Oslo">Oslo</a> in Norway.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[230]</a></sup> In 2012, Copenhagen Harbour handled 372 cruise ships and 840,000 passengers. As a result of the growth in the cruise industry facilities are being expanded and improved. At the World Travel Awards in 2012, Copenhagen Port was once again named Europe's leading cruise port after receiving the award every year since 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[231]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bikecultureincopenhagen.jpg" title="File:Bikecultureincopenhagen.jpg">File:Bikecultureincopenhagen.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Cycling to work</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Metro" title="Copenhagen Metro">Copenhagen Metro</a> and the <a href="/wiki/S-train" title="S-train">S-train</a> networks are used by about half of the city's passengers, the remainder using bus services. <a href="/w/index.php?title=N%C3%B8rreport_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nørreport Station (page does not exist)">Nørreport Station</a> near the city centre serves passengers travelling by main-line rail, S-train, metro and bus. Some 750,000 passengers make use of public transport facilities every day.<sup id="cite_ref-nt_232-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nt-232">[232]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Central_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Central Station (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Central Station</a> is the hub of the <a href="/wiki/DSB_(railway_company)" title="DSB (railway company)">DSB</a> railway network serving Denmark and international destinations.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[233]</a></sup>
</p><p>Copenhagen has an extensive road network including motorways connecting the city to other parts of Denmark and to Sweden over the <a href="/wiki/%C3%98resund_Bridge" title="Øresund Bridge">Øresund Bridge</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nt_232-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nt-232">[232]</a></sup> The car is still the most popular form of transport within the city itself, representing two-thirds of all distances travelled. This can however lead to serious congestion in rush hour traffic.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[234]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Danish capital is known as one of the most <a href="/wiki/Bicycle-friendly" title="Bicycle-friendly">bicycle-friendly</a> cities in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[235]</a></sup> Every day 1.2&#160;million km are covered by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cycling_in_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cycling in Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Copenhagen's cyclists</a>. Some 37% of all citizens cycle to work, school or university. The city's <a href="/wiki/Segregated_cycle_facilities" title="Segregated cycle facilities">bicycle paths</a> are extensive and well used. Bicycle paths are often separated from the main traffic lanes and sometimes have their own signal systems, giving the cyclists a lead of a couple of seconds to accelerate.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[236]</a></sup>
<br style="clear:both;" />
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Healthcare">Healthcare</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rigshospitalet_Copenhagen_2005-11.jpg" title="File:Rigshospitalet Copenhagen 2005-11.jpg">File:Rigshospitalet Copenhagen 2005-11.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Rigshospitalet" title="Rigshospitalet">Rigshospitalet</a></div></div></div>
<p>Promoting health is an extremely important issue for Copenhagen's municipal authorities. Central to its sustainability mission is its "Long Live Copenhagen" (<i>Længe Leve København</i>) scheme in which it has the goal of increasing the life expectancy of citizens, improving quality of life through better standards of health, and encouraging more productive lives and equal opportunities.<sup id="cite_ref-kkhealth_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kkhealth-237">[237]</a></sup> The city has targets to encourage people to exercise regularly and to reduce the number who smoke and consume alcohol.<sup id="cite_ref-kkhealth_237-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kkhealth-237">[237]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_University_Hospital&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen University Hospital (page does not exist)">Copenhagen University Hospital</a> forms a conglomerate of several hospitals in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Region_Hovedstaden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Region Hovedstaden (page does not exist)">Region Hovedstaden</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Region_Sj%C3%A6lland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Region Sjælland (page does not exist)">Region Sjælland</a>, together with the faculty of <a href="/wiki/Health_sciences" title="Health sciences" class="mw-redirect">health sciences</a> at the University of Copenhagen; <a href="/wiki/Rigshospitalet" title="Rigshospitalet">Rigshospitalet</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bispebjerg_Hospital&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bispebjerg Hospital (page does not exist)">Bispebjerg Hospital</a> in Copenhagen belong to this group of university hospitals.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Rigshospitalet began operating in March 1757 as Frederiks Hospital,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> and became state-owned in 1903. With 1,120 beds, Rigshospitalet has responsibility for 65,000 inpatients and approximately 420,000 outpatients annually. It seeks to be the number one specialist hospital in the country, with an extensive team of researchers into cancer treatment, surgery and radiotherapy.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[238]</a></sup>  In addition to its 8,000 personnel, the hospital has training and hosting functions. It benefits from the presence of in-service students of medicine and other healthcare sciences, as well as scientists working under a variety of research grants. The hospital became internationally famous as the location of <a href="/wiki/Lars_von_Trier" title="Lars von Trier">Lars von Trier</a>'s television horror mini-series <i><a href="/wiki/Riget" title="Riget" class="mw-redirect">The Kingdom</a></i>. Bispebjerg Hospital was built in 1913, and serves about 400,000 people in the Greater Copenhagen area, with some 3,000 employees.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[239]</a></sup> Other large hospitals in the city include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amager_Hospital&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amager Hospital (page does not exist)">Amager Hospital</a> (1997),<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[240]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hvidovre_Hospital&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hvidovre Hospital (page does not exist)">Hvidovre Hospital</a> (1970),<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[241]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gentofte_Hospital&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gentofte Hospital (page does not exist)">Gentofte Hospital</a> (1927).<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[242]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Politiken_building.jpg" title="File:Politiken building.jpg">File:Politiken building.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i>Politiken</i> building on the City Hall Square</div></div></div>
<p>Many Danish media corporations are located in Copenhagen. <a href="/wiki/DR_(broadcaster)" title="DR (broadcaster)">DR</a>, the major Danish <a href="/wiki/Public_broadcasting" title="Public broadcasting">public service</a> broadcasting corporation collected their activities in a new headquarters, <a href="/w/index.php?title=DR_Byen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="DR Byen (page does not exist)">DR Byen</a>, in 2006 and 2007. Similarly <a href="/wiki/TV_2_(Denmark)" title="TV 2 (Denmark)">TV2</a> which is based in <a href="/wiki/Odense" title="Odense">Odense</a> has concentrated its Copenhagen activities in a modern media house in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Teglholmen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Teglholmen (page does not exist)">Teglholmen</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[243]</a></sup> The two national daily newspapers <i><a href="/wiki/Politiken" title="Politiken">Politiken</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Berlingske_Tidende&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Berlingske Tidende (page does not exist)">Berlingske Tidende</a></i> and the two <a href="/wiki/Tabloid_(newspaper_format)" title="Tabloid (newspaper format)">tabloids</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Ekstra_Bladet" title="Ekstra Bladet">Ekstra Bladet</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=B.T._(tabloid)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="B.T. (tabloid) (page does not exist)">B.T.</a></i> are based in Copenhagen.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[244]</a></sup> Other important media corporations include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aller_Media&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aller Media (page does not exist)">Aller Media</a> which is the largest publisher of weekly and monthly magazines in <a href="/wiki/Scandinavia" title="Scandinavia">Scandinavia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[245]</a></sup> the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Egmont_Publishing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Egmont Publishing (page does not exist)">Egmont</a> <a href="/wiki/Media_conglomerate" title="Media conglomerate">media group</a><sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[246]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gyldendal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gyldendal (page does not exist)">Gyldendal</a>, the largest Danish publisher of books.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[247]</a></sup>
</p><p>Copenhagen also has a sizable film and television industry. <a href="/wiki/Nordisk_Film" title="Nordisk Film">Nordisk Film</a>, established in Valby, Copenhagen in 1906 is the oldest continuously operating film production company in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Timeline_196-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Timeline-196">[196]</a></sup> In 1992 it merged with the Egmont media group and currently runs the 17-screen <a href="/w/index.php?title=Palads_Cinema&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Palads Cinema (page does not exist)">Palads Cinema</a> in Copenhagen. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Filmbyen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Filmbyen (page does not exist)">Filmbyen</a> (movie city), located in a former <a href="/wiki/Military_camp" title="Military camp">military camp</a> in the suburb of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hvidovre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hvidovre (page does not exist)">Hvidovre</a>, houses several movie companies and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Movie_studio&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Movie studio (page does not exist)">studios</a>. Among the movie companies is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Zentropa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zentropa (page does not exist)">Zentropa</a>, co-owned by Danish <a href="/w/index.php?title=Film_director&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Film director (page does not exist)">movie director</a> <a href="/wiki/Lars_von_Trier" title="Lars von Trier">Lars von Trier</a> who is behind several international movie productions as well as a founding force behind the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dogme_95&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dogme 95 (page does not exist)">Dogme Movement</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[248]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=CPH:PIX&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="CPH:PIX (page does not exist)">CPH:PIX</a> is Copenhagen's international feature film festival, established in 2009 as a fusion of the 20-year-old <a href="/w/index.php?title=NatFilm_Festival&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NatFilm Festival (page does not exist)">Natfilm festival</a> and the four-year-old CIFF. The CPH:PIX festival takes place in mid-April.  <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_International_Documentary_Festival&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen International Documentary Festival (page does not exist)">CPH:DOX</a> is Copenhagen's international documentary film festival, every year in November. On top of its documentary film programme of over 100 films, CPH:DOX includes a wide <a href="/w/index.php?title=Programme_(booklet)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Programme (booklet) (page does not exist)">event programme</a> with dozens of events, concerts, exhibitions and parties all over town.<sup id="cite_ref-cphpix1_249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cphpix1-249">[249]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notable_people">Notable people</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>

<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Jussi_Adler-Olsen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jussi Adler-Olsen (page does not exist)">Jussi Adler-Olsen</a>, bestseller author
</li>

</li>

</li>

</li>

</li>

</li>

</li>

</li>

</li>

</li>

</li>

</li>

</li>

</li>

</li>

</li>

</li>

</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mikkel_Kessler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mikkel Kessler (page does not exist)">Mikkel Kessler</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">boxing</a> great
</li>

</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Kim_Larsen" title="Kim Larsen">Kim Larsen</a>, singer, guitarist and songwriter
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Michael_Laudrup" title="Michael Laudrup">Michael Laudrup</a>, former football player, currently coach
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Bj%C3%B8rn_Lomborg" title="Bjørn Lomborg">Bjørn Lomborg</a>, political scientist and author
</li>

</li>

</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ghita_N%C3%B8rby&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ghita Nørby (page does not exist)">Ghita Nørby</a>, film actress
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Deepika_Padukone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Deepika Padukone (page does not exist)">Deepika Padukone</a>, Bollywood actress
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Dirch_Passer" title="Dirch Passer">Dirch Passer</a>, comedian and actor
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ren%C3%A9_Redzepi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="René Redzepi (page does not exist)">René Redzepi</a>, chef and co-owner of the two-Michelin star restaurant <a href="/w/index.php?title=Noma_(restaurant)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Noma (restaurant) (page does not exist)">Noma</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peter_Schmeichel" title="Peter Schmeichel">Peter Schmeichel</a>, TV host, former footballer
</li>

</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Anders_Trentem%C3%B8ller&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anders Trentemøller (page does not exist)">Anders Trentemøller</a>, electronic/techno musician and remixer for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trentem%C3%B8ller&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trentemøller (page does not exist)">Trentemøller</a>
</li>

</li>

</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Lars_Ulrich" title="Lars Ulrich">Lars Ulrich</a>, drummer and songwriter for <a href="/wiki/Heavy_metal_music" title="Heavy metal music">heavy metal</a> band <a href="/wiki/Metallica" title="Metallica">Metallica</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Link_Wray" title="Link Wray">Link Wray</a>, guitarist
</li>

</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/J%C3%B8rn_Utzon" title="Jørn Utzon">Jørn Utzon</a>, architect
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lars_Eller&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lars Eller (page does not exist)">Lars Eller</a>, NHL player
</li>
</ul>

</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Twin_cities">Twin cities</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Col-begin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Col-begin (page does not exist)">Template:Col-begin</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Col-3&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Col-3 (page does not exist)">Template:Col-3</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_PRC&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data PRC (page does not exist)">Template:Country data PRC</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beijing (page does not exist)">Beijing</a>, <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> <sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[250]</a></sup>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_GER&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data GER (page does not exist)">Template:Country data GER</a> <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Country_data_BRA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Country data BRA (page does not exist)">Template:Country data BRA</a> <a href="/wiki/Curitiba" title="Curitiba">Curitiba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>
</li>
</ul>

</p>
<ul>

</li>
</ul>

</p>
<ul>

</li>

</li>
</ul>

<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Reflist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Reflist (page does not exist)">Template:Reflist</a>
</p>
<dl>
<dt>Bibliography
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
